loans.name: Elsa Maria

texts.es: La Sra. Elsa María Hernández Z.  ella se desempeña como vendedora de ropa usada y nueva tiene de dedicarse a esta actividad  once  años,  ella es casada actualmente. Ha tenido  tres créditos con CEPRODEL y este crédito él lo está solicitando para la compra de una paca de ropa usada y ropa nueva  y para ampliar y mejorar su negocio y su vida familiar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Elsa Maria H. Z. is married and makes a living by selling new and used clothing, an activity which she has done for eleven years. She has had three loans with CEPRODEL, and this one will be used for the purchase of a package of used clothing and one of new clothing in order to expand and improve her business and her family life.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a package of used and new clothing

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa K. is a single parent who is staying with her four children. She had a commercial system of education where she was taught how to make tie and dye clothing. (In tie and dye, designs are first tied or stitched into the cloth, using cotton or raffia threads.) Adwoa sells cloth in Jukwa, which she has been doing for some time now. 

Adowa uses her income to pay for her rent and other expenditures. Adwoa will use the loan to purchase more cloths for sale. With the new profits from her extended business, Adwoa plans to save to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth for sale

loans.name: Milenia Del Carmen

texts.es: La Sra. Milena del Carmen Gutiérrez M.  ella se desempeña como comerciante de la carne de cerdo y vende pan  tiene de dedicarse a esta actividad  veinte y dos años,  ella es casada actualmente. Ha tenido  doce créditos con CEPRODEL y este crédito ella lo está solicitando para la compra de dos cerdos para destazarlo y compra de materia prima para hacer pan, ella con el préstamo se ayuda en su negocio y en su vida   familiar.
texts.en:
Milena del Carmen Gutiérrez M. works as a merchant selling pork and bread. She has been carrying out this activity for 22 years. She is currently married. She has taken 12 loans with CEPRODEL, and this loan will be used to buy 2 pigs to slaughter, and to buy raw materials to make bread. This loan will help Milena with her business and with her family life.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy 2 pigs to slaughter, and flour and corn to make bread to sell

loans.name: Mikhail

texts.en:
Mikhail is married with a 3-year-old son. He lives in Kamenka. Mikhail grows agricultural produce which he sells in the local markets. He owns two big, arch greenhouses and two simple ones where he grows seedlings. Mikhail built his first greenhouse 5 years ago. Currently he has invested about 70,000 Grivnyas in this venture. Annually he spends about 10,000 – 12,000 Grivnyas on seeds and polyethylene film. 

Mikhail is seeking a loan of 5,000 Grivnyas to purchase a drip irrigation unit and to reconstruct his greenhouse for this spring farming season. In the near future, Mikhail is hoping to construct one more greenhouse on an additional piece of property that he owns, and to expand his business as a result.

loans.use: to purchase a drip irrigation unit and to reconstruct his greenhouse

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa K. sells plantain, fresh pepper, cassava and other food stuffs at Jukwa. Adwoa has not received any form of education. She is divorced and has three children. She is responsible for feeding and clothing her children, as well as providing good quality education for them. Her loan will be used to buy more plantains and other food stuffs for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save up to build on a piece of land she has already acquired.

loans.use: to buy more plantains and other food stuffs for sale.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is married with two grown sons. She is an entrepreneur from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine. Leonora sells women’s footwear in the marketplace, next to the local bus station. This is a busy vending spot which is always crowded with potential customers. Leonora has been working in this trade for 10 years. Presently, she has 7,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her gross income is about 3,500 Grivnyas a month. 

Leonora is requesting a loan of 7,500 Grivnyas to increase her working capital and to restock her merchandise. This will help her to generate additional income and keep her business stable. Leonora has a long, good credit history. She is known as an entrepreneur of integrity. We believe her good record and honest approach in business matters will guarantee prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: to increase her working capital

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua A. is a single parent living with her four children. She has received no formal education. Ekua goes to the nearby villages to buy yam in large quantities to sell at Jukwa market. Ekua uses her income to take care of her children. Ekua will use the loan to purchase more yams so that she can meet the demand of her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to save to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: to purchase more yams to meet customer demand

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. sells fried fish at Jukwa. Aba has Junior High school education. She is married and has seven dependants. Her husband works with the electoral commission of Ghana. 

Aba has been selling fried fish for some time now. She buys the fish fresh from the fishermen, comes home to dress it neatly, adds a little spice to it and later fries it for sale to her customers. She provides a helping hand in the upkeep of the entire family. 

Her loan will be used to buy more varieties of fresh fish to fry for sale. She hopes to use the new earnings from her business to save in order to further her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy more varieties of fresh fish to fry for sale.

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed Bibi is the wife of R. A.. She lives in a city named Vehari in Pakistan. Her house consists of four rooms. She has given birth to five children, three sons and two daughters. Two of her sons are over 18 and they are daily wage laborers. Her husband has a business selling sweetmeat and fruits. He has been selling these items for over 30 years. He has obtained a good reputation in the market. 

Khursheed stays at home and takes care of her family. She has fully repaid her first loan to Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan and Kiva partner). Now she is applying again for her husband so he can purchase items such as dry fruits, sugar, cooking oil, etc., and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy items for sweetmeat-selling business

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia K. is a happily married woman with three children. She has received a senior-high education. Afia sells garden eggs and various types of spices in Jukwa, which she has been doing for about three years now. Her husband is a farmer.  

Afia uses the income she gets from the sale of garden eggs to help her husband in taking care of the family. Afia will use the loan she is going to get to purchase additional bags of garden eggs to resell to those who cook in large quantities. With the new earnings from her expanded business, Afia plans to save to build a shop at the marketplace to sell in.

This picture was taken on a market day (a day set aside for the market women to display all their goods and sell them at a reduced price.) A lot of people do their buying on this day.

loans.use: To purchase additional bags of garden eggs to resell to those who cook in large quantities

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena Z. processes palm oil for sale at Jukwa. Abena has Junior High School education. She is married and has a child. Her husband is a farmer. She helps to take care of the entire home. The loan will be used to buy more palm fruits to process her palm oil for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save up to build a house.

To prepare her locally made palm oil, she gets palm nuts from the farmers. She washes them and boils them for about forty minutes until they become soft and tender. The cooked fruits are scooped into a big mortar and gently squashed with a pestle, avoiding damaging the nut, and only squeezing out the juice covering the pulp. Once this is done, the juice is filtered to remove the chaff (the chaff is sometimes used by the local people to light charcoal fires). The juice is boiled again and, as it boils, the fresh oil will be seen floating on top. This is scooped into yet another pot and left to cool. Fresh oil from palm fruits is traditionally used when eating roasted yam or plantain in Africa, especially on the farms, after a hard days work.

loans.use: to buy more palm fruits to process her palm oil for sale.

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida is the wife of M. A. and lives in a city called Vehari in Pakistan. She is the mother of seven children: five sons and two daughters. Four of her children are studying in school in different classes. Her husband has a fruit selling business: he sells fruit from a cart in various locations.


Zubaida is a very kind lady. She takes care of her children, her family and her house. She has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan for the fourth time so that her husband can buy fruit and expand his business. They are expecting a good profit from this loan and it will be helpful in improving their living standard.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit to sell

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. is a married woman who is a seamstress at Jukwa. She makes both male and female clothing, but most of her customers are females. Customers come to her home to place their orders. 

Esi has junior high school education and has a child. Her husband is a teacher. She helps her husband pay for accommodation and utility bills. She will add the loan to her income to buy materials to sew and also to buy ladies shoes as an additional product line (goods for sale). She hopes to use the new profits from her expanded trade to save up to acquire a shop.

loans.use: to buy sewing materials and ladies shoes as an additional product line

loans.name: Magrina

texts.en:
Magrina C. is 45 years and is married to Peter Kiptoo who is a police man. They live in Kaptara with their six children who are aged between 8 and 24. 

Magrina runs a grocery shop which she started 17 years ago. She makes a monthly profit of Kshs 5,000 and an additional income of Kshs 1,000 from horticultural farming. Her grocery shop is situated in Kaptara Centre and most of her clients are residents of Kaptara Centre.

Magrina came to know of KADET from her current group officials. She has a credit history with another microfinance institution. With this loan of Kshs 15,000 she will buy groceries for sale. If this loan boosts her business, she plans to open a big agro-vet shop.

Magrina describes herself as hard working.

loans.use: to buy additional stock for the grocery business

loans.name: Senyi Tusitukirewamu Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Prossy, shown with her hand raised in the group photo, is an easygoing, 34-year-old woman running a ten-year-old retail business in Senyi, Lugazi district. She is a happily married mother with four rowdy schoolchildren.

In her shop, Prossy sells essential household items like sugar, beans, soap, and maize flour. The good rapport she has had with her customers from the start of her business has ensured she basks in some minimal success. Her good business graces have manifestly brought her to a point where she currently earns almost 70,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis.

After she had quite an engrossing experience working as a shopkeeper, Prossy ventured into her own business enterprise. With this loan, she hopes to significantly increase her retail business stock in a short period of time. She also hopes to educate all her kids fully to university level.

loans.use: To buy more beans, sugar, maize flour, soap, salt and so on

loans.name: Lucrecia Juana

texts.es:
Juana P. de 39 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Paraíso de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y solo cuenta con luz y agua como servicio básico. Es madre soltera de una niña que estudia en una escuela fiscal. 

Juana desde los 17 años aprendió a coser con su familia, empezó a ser costurera desde muy temprana edad y ha trabajar con empresas entregando ropa. Ha sus 28 años decidió independizarse  comprando una maquina de coser con sus ahorros. 

En la actualidad tiene 2 empleados trabajando con ella su hermana en ocasiones le ayuda. La delincuencia es uno de los mayores inconvenientes que tiene para elaborar con más eficiencia su negocio. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar telas de uniforme porque en abril es la temporada escolar y tiene muchos uniformes que entregar. En el futuro quiere trasladar su taller a un lugar más seguro y contar con más personas trabajando en su taller.
texts.en:
Juana P. is 39 years old. She lives in a semi-urban zone of Paraíso de Guayaqui. Her house is made of cement and only has light and water as its basic amenities. She is a single mother of a young daughter who attends public school. When she was 17 years old, Juana learned how to sew from her family members. She was a seamstress at a very early age and has worked with businesses making clothes. When she was 28 years old, she decided to become independent and bought a sewing machine with her savings. Juana currently has two employees working for her. Sometimes her sister helps her. Crime is one of the major inconveniences that prevents her from having a more efficient business. With this loan, Juana wants to buy fabric for school uniforms because April is the beginning of the school year and she has a lot of uniforms to make. In the future she wants to move her business to a safer area and have more people working for her.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Uniform fabric

loans.name: Salinah

texts.en:
Salinah S., 45, is married to Benjamin Ossen who is 54yrs old and an employee of Kuda (Kerio Valley Development Authority). They live in Kaptimbor Village and have four children who are aged between 7 and 27.

Salinah sells groceries in Kabarnet Market. Her clients are residents of Kabarnet. She started this business four years ago and normally makes a profit of Kshs 4,000 per month. 

Salina was introduced to Kadet Limited by an existing client. She has a credit history with another microfinance institution. She has applied for a loan of Kshs 20,000 which she will use to purchase sugar and other goods for sale and to purchase second-hand clothes for sale. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the extra profit to open a wholesale shop. 

She hopes to open a self selection shop in future and she describes herself as hardworking

loans.use: to purchase groceries and second-hand clothes for sale

loans.name: Sivaitoa

texts.en:
Sivaitoa F. is 53 and married with 7 children.  She owns a business venture, 0 bbq.  Sivaitoa has 5 years of experience in this business.  Sivaitoa needs a loan of WST $1000 to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Sivaitoa joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sivaitoa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Malia

texts.en:
Malia M. is 65 and married with 65 children.  She owns a business venture, selling lavalavas (bottom-half wrap-around prints worn by both men and women).  Malia has 6 years of experience in this business.  Malia needs a loan of WST $2500 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Malia joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Malia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Ledisha

texts.en:
Ledisha is a 36 year old, married lady. She is married to a gentleman called Shadrack Kiprotich and together they have been blessed with three children aged 4, 7 and 9. She practices small scale farming and makes bricks as a part-time job to increase her income.

She has applied for her first loan from Kadet. She intends to buy maize and bean seeds for planting on her farm. She also plans to buy some additional hens for meat and egg production.

loans.use: To purchase maize and bean seeds, fertilizers and additional hens

loans.name: Las Atrevidas Group

texts.es:
La señora Maria Estela L. C. es presidenta de un grupo de 11 personas cada una de ellas con diferentes actividades productivas que se juntaron para solicitar crédito a Fundación Realidad. El grupo lleva por nombre Las Atrevidas, le pusieron ese nombre porque se atreven a pedir dinero para trabajar. Se conocen por que ya han tenido experiencias en conjunto con los créditos, con otra institución, pero decidieron cambiar buscando un mejor servicio y una menor tasa de interés.
La Señora Maria Estela es originaria y vecina de una comunidad llamada San Marcos, Dentro de la Costa Chica del Estado de Guerrero, en México. La Comunidad cuenta con 13,000 habitantes, siendo Cabecera Municipal, sus habitantes se dedican principalmente a actividades agropecuarias y al comercio.
La señora Maria estela  tiene 39 años de edad, cuenta con una escolaridad de 2º de secundaria, esta casada, su esposo es taxista, y cuenta con 2 hijos que estudian primaria.
Tiene 2 actividades económicas de donde provienen sus ingresos con los que ayuda a la economía familiar por las mañanas cuenta con un molino de nixtamal donde ofrece el servicio de molienda de maíz y venta de masa, y por las tardes vende comidas, antojitos mexicanos.
Con el molino de nixtamal tiene 11 años y con la venta de comidas por las tardes apenas 2 semanas. El crédito lo necesita para hacer crecer su negocio además quiere poner otro giro que es la venta de verduras, ya que quiere seguir creciendo en sus actividades productivas.
Los integrantes del grupo asi como sus actividades productivas son los siguientes:

Nombre	Actividad económica
Maria Estela L. C.	Molino de nixtamal y venta de comidas
Maria Luisa D. Teresa	Venta de ropa
Clemencia M. V.	Cocina económica para venta de comidas
Susana C. García	        Venta de refrescos
Petra Jiménez R.	        Venta de frutas y verduras
Maria Matilde D. T.	Venta de frutas y verduras
Alejandra C. S.	Elaboración y venta de pan
Pedro C. J.	        Cocina económica para venta de comidas
Gloria Jiménez V.	Venta de refrescos
Paula M. R.	        Venta de frutas y verduras
Epifania T. L.	        Venta de dulces
texts.en:
Maria Estela L. C. is the president of a group of 11 women, each of whom works in different areas. They got together to ask for a loan from Fundación Realidad ("Reality Foundation"). The group is called Las Atrevidas ("The Daring Ones"). They gave themselves this name because they dare to ask for money for their businesses. The women know each other because they have had experience with other group loans with another institution, but they decided to change looking for better service and lower interest rates. Maria Estela is a native and resident of a community called San Marcos in Costa Chica in the Mexican state of Guerrero. The community has 13,000 residents, as it is the municipal capital. Its inhabitants work mainly in agriculture or business. Maria is 39 years old and has a secondary education. She is married to a taxi driver. They have two children who are in primary school. She has two economic activities that provide revenue she uses to help with household costs. In the mornings, she works in a corn mill where she mills corn and sells cornmeal. In the afternoons, she sells food like typical Mexican snacks. She has worked 11 years in the corn mill and two weeks selling food. She needs the loan to be able to grow her business. Additionally, she wants to add another direction to her business with vegetable sales, because she wants to continue growing through her work. The following is a list of the members of the group and their work: Maria Estela L. C. - Corn mill and food sales Maria Luisa D. Teresa - Clothing sales Clemencia M. V. - Cooking for food sales Susana C. García - Drink sales Petra Jiménez R. - Fruit and vegetable sales Maria Matilde D. T. - Fruit and vegetable sales Alejandra C. S. - Baking and selling bread Pedro C. J. - Cooking for food sales Gloria Jiménez V. - Drink sales Paula M. R. - Fruit and vegetable sales Epifania T. L. - Candy sales

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise to increase sale of cornmeal and Mexican food

location.town: Localidad de San Marcos, Municipio de San Marcos,

loans.name: Senyi Tusitukirewamu Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en:
Meet S. Robert, a 32-year-old father of three. Shown in the photo with hand raised, he is the leader of his lending group.

Robert’s journey into business began with a few savings from his farming activities in the village of Kiwungi in Lugazi. From his small savings this determined man began a retail shop in 2005. This has since then been his only source of income for his family.

From his growing business, Robert has painstakingly catered for his family’s welfare. His success calling card in his business, he says, has been that close acquaintance chord he has developed with his clients. At present his business draws him close to 100,000 shillings a week.

With this loan, Robert reckons on a revamping spree for his business - that is, buying more stock for his shop. He is such a strong and delightful man.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, maize flour, soap and so on

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace K. is 38 years old and is married to Philip Kurui, 40, who is an administrative police officer. She lives in Karpropita with her family of five children. 

Grace operates a retail shop in Kapropita which she started ten years ago. She makes a monthly profit of Kshs 15,000 from this business and other sources.

Grace was introduced to KADET by existing clients. This is her first source of funding and she has applied for a loan which she will use to rent and prepare land for farming. The amount will cover the rental, labor and purchase of seedlings required. She anticipates a boost in her business and she will use the extra profit to start a poultry farming project where she intends to keep both broilers and layers.

Her future dream is poultry farming which she wishes to start using the extra profit generated from her business as a result of the loan. Grace describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: to rent land for tilling and to purchase seedlings

loans.name: Fialelei

texts.en:
"The following social metrics for Fialelei N. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

Fialelei N. is 64 and widowed with 11 children.  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Fialelei has 5 years of experience in this business.  Fialelei needs a loan of WST $3000 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2006, Fialelei joined SPBD.    This is her 5th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Fialelei's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 27 years old and is married to Mr.N.. They have four children who go to a nearby school. She makes bricks, with the help of her husband, and also practices small scale farming.

She was introduced to Kadet by a friend who is also a member of Kadet. She has applied for her first loan with Kadet which she intends to use to buy more materials for making bricks as there is a high demand for bricks in her area. She will also buy seeds to plant in her farm.

Her future plans are to supply bricks to new markets away from her local area. She will, therefore, increase her income and be able to educate all her children and build a bigger house.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making bricks and seeds for planting

loans.name: Uini

texts.en:
Uini  F. is 35 and married with 2 children.  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Uini  has 5 years of experience in this business.  Uini  needs a loan of WST $1700 to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Uini  joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Uini 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is a young man of twenty-three, single, and with no children. He lives in Lusweti in Eldoret and does maize farming which he has done for four years now. 

He was introduced to KADET by another KADET client, and this will be his first loan in KADET. He plans to use the entire loan on his farm to buy farm inputs like fertilizers, maize seedlings and herbicides.

However, Joel does not only do maize farming but also sells milk to his neighbors who are mostly teachers and other farmers around. His dream and goal in life is to eradicate poverty in his homeland by providing jobs (employment) to people around him.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like fertilizer, herbicide, etc.

loans.name: Uaina

texts.en:
Uaina F. is 44 and married with 10 children.  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Uaina has many years of experience in this business.  Uaina needs a loan of WST $1700 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Uaina joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Uaina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin C. was born in 1956. He is married to Salina, who is 48 years old. They have four children: Isaac, Norah, George and Douglas. Benjamin runs a charcoal business that he started ten years ago. He gets a profit of Kshs 5,000 every month from this business. His business is in Kabarnet, a town where competition among charcoal suppliers is rare, so he has very loyal customers.

Benjamin was introduced to KADET by existing clients. He has borrowed a loan of Kshs 20,000 that he will use to buy more sacks of charcoal for his business inventory. If this loan boosts his business, he will use the extra profit to expand his business and sell in wholesale quantities. 

Benjamin hopes to be a famous charcoal wholesaler and own a lorry which will enable him to supply charcoal to big towns. He describes himself as hardworking, faithful and God-fearing.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Litia

texts.en:
Litia  F. is 48 and married with 3 children.  She owns a business venture, selling lavalavas (bottom-half wrap-around prints worn by both men and women).  Litia  has many years of experience in this business.  Litia  needs a loan of WST $2100 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Litia  joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Litia 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Enock Kimutai

texts.en:
Enock K. is 30 years old and married to Irene Chemuge, who is a farmer. They have been blessed with one child, Kemboi K., who is one year old.

Enock owns a mobile phone accessories shop in Kabarnet Town, where the residents are his main customers. Enock gets a profit of Kshs 21,000 from this business and others sources of monthly income.
  
Enock was introduced to Kadet Ltd. by a friend who had already joint Kadet. He has borrowed a loan of Kshs 53,000, which is his third loan from Kadet. He plans to use Kshs 45000 to purchase charcoal for his business. The remaining amount will be used to pay rent and other overhead costs of the business.

If this loan boosts his business, Enock will use the extra profit to expand the business. His dreams of having a good business future and, thereby, being able to purchase a car. He describes himself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: Loan will be used to buy charcoal, restock the business, and pay rent

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas is 32 years old. He is married to Jackline Kiptanui and both live in Kabarnet Town. Douglas runs a posho mill (a grinding machine that crushes maize into flour) that he started two years ago. He gets a monthly profit of Ksh.8000, and additional income from farming.

Douglas was introduced to KADET Ltd. by an existing client. He has borrowed Kshs. 40000 from Kadet. This is his first loan from any MFI (micro-finance institution. He will use the loan to buy maize and millet for his milling business. If this loan boosts his business, he will use the extra profit to expand the business.

Douglas hopes and dreams of going back to school for further studies, of buying a lorry for fast transport of maize and millet, and of having a plot of land in the town. He describes himself as honest, faithful, hardworking, and sober-minded.

loans.use: To buying more stock for his posho mill

loans.name: Roseta

texts.en:
Roseta L. is 39 and married with 4 children (ages 5 - 16).  She is starting a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Roseta needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Roseta joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Roseta's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Loise

texts.en:
Loise operates her electronics shop in Ndunyu Njeru, which is a rural town in Kenya.  Her stock of electronics consists of basic electrical goods and cheap ones to cater to her client base.  She sells mobile phones, mobile phones spare parts, and other goods, like radios and TV sets, all for the low-end target market. She is 37 years old and married to James Mbugua. They have three school-going children. 

She was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her first loan. She plans to buy more mobile phone spare parts to stock her shop. In the future, she plans to expand her shop and be a major supplier of electronic goods in Ndunyu Njeru.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phone spare parts to sell

loans.name: Bbogo Women's Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en:
Nantumbe Margaret, with hand raised, is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a 52-year-old single woman, but a happy-go-lucky and cheerful business woman.

Margaret’s ten-year-old flourishing fish-vending business in Kombwe, Lugazi, has enabled her to give her six children an education. Her modest business has been generating her profits to the tune of 30,000 shillings per week.

With this new loan, Margaret wants to be financially empowered and to buy more fish, which she hopes to sell not only to old clients but also to new ones.

Margaret got inclined to this business after her erstwhile husband prevailed upon her to join him. Since then, she has never looked back, notwithstanding the marital adversities the family had. She wants to buy another canoe boat to facilitate easy delivery of fish to her operating area as well as to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy another canoe boat and to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Tumema

texts.en:
Tumema T. is 51 and single with no children.  She owns a business venture, providing dress making services to local community members.  Tumema has 3 years of experience in this business.  Tumema needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Tumema joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Tumema's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

texts.en:

Tolfi needs a loan of WST $1250 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Tolfi joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Tolfi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Maria needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 280 talas or US $117 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

Tetee needs a loan of WST $1500 to expand shelter for the borrower's livestock.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

texts.en:

Selepa needs a loan of WST $2250 to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to financially support extended members of her family.

In 2006, Selepa joined SPBD.  This is her 6th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Selepa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana Barón E., tiene 61 años y es una mujer emprendedora que maneja simultáneamente a  2 negocios, por un lado vende mercancías variadas como ropa, accesorios cubre lechos, sobrecamas  y por otro lado  pescado especialmente bocachico, pargo, y mojarra.
 
Desde los 25 años llegó a Barranquilla desde  su natal San Onofre en el departamento de  Sucre,  cuando nació su primera hija sintió la necesidad de obtener mas ingresos extras y con el producto de su trabajo  de 5 años como  empleada doméstica y en restaurantes,  se dedicó a vender mercancía traída desde Valledupar en el Cesar y también desde Maicao  en la Guajira.  Así fue como empezó a comercializar juegos de sabanas,  toallas, labor que realizó durante 10 años. Ya en el  año 1998,  empezó a vender pescado  que le compraba a su hermana  y construyó una clientela fija,  con más de 25 a 30 clientes de diferentes barrios como El Recreo, Las Delicias, Boston  y actualmente combina perfectamente sus dos actividades  las cuales les generan ingresos a crédito y de contado, como en el caso del pescado.

Este es el cuarto crédito con la Fundación, ellos han cambiado positivamente su entorno comercial, pues así puede hacer compras en mayor volumen y también puede responde a nuevos clientes con los que ellos necesiten.
Su sueño es lograr montar un pequeño almacén donde pueda ofrecer sus mercancías ella quiere una  especie de boutique, porque su negocio marcha bien y tiene una clientela exclusiva que ha ido escogiendo a través de los años, ellos  son profesores y empleados a quienes les acredita y ellos le pagan cada quince días.
texts.en:
Juana Barón E. is 61 years old. She is an entreprenuerial woman who manages two businesses simultaneously: selling various merchandise like clothes, quilts, and bedspreads on one end and selling fish like bocachico, snapper, and tilapia on the other. At age 25 she came to Barranquilla from her hometown San Onofre in the department of Sucre. When her first daughter was born she felt the need to make more money. As a result of her five years working as a maid and in restaurants, she was able to begin selling merchandise brought from Valledupar in Cesar and from Maicao in Guajira. This is how she began selling sets of sheets and towels, which she did over ten years. In 1998, she began selling fish that her sister bought for her. She built up a solid customer base with more than 25 to 30 clients from different neighborhoods like El Recreo, Las Delicias, and Boston. Her two businesses complement each other well, generating income through credit and cash, as is the case with the fish. This is her fourth loan with the Foundation. The loans have impacted her business environment positively, by allowing her to make higher-volume purchases and respond to the needs of new customers. Her dream is to be able to have a small store where she can sell her merchandise. She wants a boutique since her business has been going well and she has an exclusive customer base that she has chosen over the years. They are professors and employees who she gives credit to and they pay her every fifteen days.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise like towels, sheets, dresses, and fish

loans.name: Seydy

texts.es:
Seydy M. Suarez   es una señora de 30 años de edad la cual  es una madre soltera que vive con su hijo de 10 años en una comunidad llamada Santa Fe localizada en Los Chiles, provincia de Alajuela; está comunidad se destaca por ser una zona montañosa y por estar muy cerca de la frontera norte de nuestro país. Sus principales actividades económicas son la ganadería y la agricultura específicamente se da la siembra de granos básicos, caña de azúcar, naranja.

Doña Seydy decidió hace  año un tener su propio negocio es así como inicio con una librería, considera que fue una buena idea ya que no había ninguna en su comunidad y los estudiantes tenían que viajar en Bici varias horas para poder adquirir sus materiales. Asegura que su negocio le ayudado a mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su hijo. Ella considera que es hora de dar un paso adelante y hacer más grande su librería. 

Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por ¢665000 (seiscientos sesenta y cinco  mil colones) para comprar  más libros para abastecer su librería y así brindar más y mejores servicios que puedan satisfacer las necesidades de los habitantes de la comunidad en especial los estudiantes. 

Doña Seydy es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Manantial de Santa Fe, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer  préstamo y con él espera crecer más a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito pueden ayudar a muchas madres soltera a ser exitosas como microempresarias.
texts.en:
Seydy M. Suarez is a 30 year-old woman. She is a signle mother who lives with her 10 year-old son in a community named Santa Fe located in Los Chiles in the Alajuela province. The community is known for being a mountainous zone near the northern border of the country. Her principal economic activities are livestock and agriculture, specifically the planting of basic grains, sugar cane, and oranges. A year ago, Ms. Seydy decided to start her own business, so she opened a boookstore. She thinks it was a good idea because there was no bookstore in her community and the local students had to travel hours on bike to get their materials for school. She assures her business improved the quality of life for her and her son. She believes it is time to move forward and enlarge her store. Currently, she needs a loan of ¢665000 (six hundred sixty-five thousand colones) to buy more books to stock her bookstore. This will allow her to offer greater and better services that will be able to satisfy the needs of the community, particularly the students. Ms. Seydy is a member of the community bank Manantial in Santa Fe, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan and with it she hopes to grow on a personal and economic level. She also stresses that thanks to these types of organizations and means of facilitating loans can help many single mothers be successful small businesswomen.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying books and improving store

loans.name: Kausar's Group

texts.en:
Kausar Bibi is from the mid-sized city of Vehari, Pakistan. She is the wife of M. A.. Their house consists of four rooms. She is the mother of five children, one daughter and four sons. Her eldest son works in a factory for a monthly wage. Her husband works as a mason.

Kausar stays at home and takes care of her children and family and manages the domestic chores. She has taken two loans from Asasah, a micro-finance institute in Pakistan, and successfully repaid them. Now she is applying for the third loan to purchase masonry tools for her husband so can earn a good profit and improve the standard of living of his family.

loans.use: To buy masonry tools for her husband's business

loans.name: Vaomau

texts.en:
Vaomau L. is 25 and married with 2 children.  She owns a business venture, selling ice-cakes (flavored ice in styrofoam cups).  Vaomau has 2 years of experience in this business.  Vaomau needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy sugar, styrofoam cups, and codial (flavoring).  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 180 talas or US $75 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Vaomau joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Vaomau's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy sugar, styrofoam cups, and codial (flavoring)

loans.name: Natividad

texts.es:
Natividad es un padre de familia de 25 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a su menor hijo en el sector El Imperial del distrito de Olmos, en la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a una hora y cincuenta minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde que era muy joven se dedica a brindar servicios de transporte de carga y pasajeros en una mototaxi, empezó su negocio alquilando unidades móviles para trabajarlas y poco a poco fue ahorrando el dinero que necesitaba para comprar la suya. Actualmente se vale de su vehículo para brindar servicio de transporte en la ciudad de Olmos y también en los caseríos y anexos de la zona. Cabe mencionar que el distrito de Olmos tiene una alta concentración de población en caseríos y anexos, considerados como zonas rurales.

El continuo uso brindado a su unidad móvil y los caminos accidentados que recorre diariamente brindando su servicio, han hecho que su unidad empiece a sufrir algunas fallas mecánicas que requieren de urgente reparación para su correcto funcionamiento, por ello Natividad se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en el mantenimiento y reparación de su vehículo.

Natividad es un joven responsable y trabajador, es un padre muy entregado a su joven familia y es muy estimado por las personas que lo conocen, ellos lo consideran un muchacho de confianza y servicial. Su sueño es seguir creciendo como empresario y adquirir otra mototaxi.
texts.en:
Natividad is a 25-year-old father who lives with his wife and minor child in the Imperial Section, in the Olmos District, in the province of Lambayeque. This is located an hour and forty minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Since he has been very young he has worked transporting cargo and passengers in a motorcyle/taxi. He started his business renting mobile units and using them for work. Little by little he saved enough money to buy his own vehicle. Actually, he uses his vehicle to provide transportation services in Olmos City and also to the farms and outskirts of the city. He would like to explain that the district of Olmos has a high concentration of population that live in farmhouses and in the outskirts, which is considered the rural zone. He uses his vehicle on roads that experience accidents each day in order to provide services to his customers. This has caused his vehicle to begin to experience some mechanical failures that require urgent attention in order for the vehicle to function well. This is why Natividad has seen the need to ask, for the first time from “Edpyme Alternativa”, for a loan of 1000 new soles. He will use this loan for the maintenance and repair of his vehicle. Natividad is a responsible young person and a hard worker. He is a father that is very devoted to his young family. He is well thought of by the people that know him. They consider him to be a trustworthy and helpful person. His dream is to continue growing as a businessperson and to acquire another motorcycle/taxi.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expenses related to the maintenance and repair of his motorcyle/taxi

loans.name: Eligio José

texts.es:
Este Sr. Se llama Eligio José P. Maradiaga, es casado, tiene 69 años de edad, a su cargo tiene solamente a su señora con la cual procreo Siete hijos, en el haber de su historia, este señor ha sido propietario de una venta de calzado en los años 70, fue Diputado en los años 80, y en el año 94 Alcalde de esta ciudad, actualmente goza de una pensión por vejez, y a la vez se dedica escribir una pequeña revista en la cual hace referencias históricas del pueblo  donde él habita.

Con nuestra institución ha obtenido la cantidad de seis créditos, los cuales le han servido para realizar gastos personales y este último para mejorar su vivienda, vale mencionar que en los cinco créditos otorgados anteriormente ha sido muy responsable con sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
This gentleman, Eligio José P. Maradiaga, is sixty-nine-years-old and married. He is currently responsible only for his wife, with whom he has had seven children. His past history includes owning a footwear-sales business during the 70's and being a deputy during the 80's, and in 1994 he was the mayor of his city. He currently enjoys a retirement pension while writing a little magazine related to the town where he lives. He has received six loans from our organization, which have allowed him to pay his personal expenses. He used the most recent one to improve his house. It's worth mentioning that with respect to his past five loans, he has been very responsible with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy home-improvement materials to (zinc sheets, wood, cement, sand, and nails).

loans.name: Saisii

texts.en:
Saisii N. is 25 and married with 3 children.  She owns a business venture, providing dress making services to local community members.  Saisii has 3 years of experience in this business.  Saisii needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 240 talas or US $100 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Saisii joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Saisii's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Luis Enrique

texts.es:
Luis Enrique B. G., tiene 56 años y es un ferviente juniorista, (seguidor del equipo de futbol de Barranquilla), este fue su principal inspiración cuando pasó de vender frutas,  al negocio que tiene actualmente  en la Ciudadela 20 de Julio de la ciudad de Barranquilla, donde comercializa artículos deportivos, como camisetas pantalonetas, medias, afiches, llaveros  y banderas, que inició en el año 2000 y que para él, ha sido mas rentable que el anterior en la plaza del mercado.  Luis está justamente ubicado  en las afueras de uno de los escenarios de futbol mas importante de Colombia: el estadio Metropolitano; él es pionero en su actividad y trabaja junto a su esposa (a su lado en la fotografía) durante mas de 12 horas diarias de lunes a domingo; sus clientes son los peatones, recomendados y los seguidores del  Futbol, inclusive provenientes de otros estadios del país; tiene una gran competencia pero se sostiene porque es innovador, consigue precios buenos para sus clientes  y diversifica constantemente el surtido que ofrece. En la actualidad solicita un crédito por valor de $1.300.000 para comprar artículos deportivos al pormayor  y de contado, especialmente de cada uno de los que exhibe como souvenirs, camisetas de diferentes equipos, banderas y afiches.
Sus créditos con la Fundación siempre han sido para incrementar el surtido y en alguna oportunidad con ellos pudo  salir de deudas onerosas con los paga diario. Su meta principal es pasar de la informalidad a la formalidad y convertirse en mayorista  y es que estos son precisamente sus desafíos.
texts.en:
Luis Enrique is 56 years old and a die-hard Barranquila soccer fan. This was his main inspiration when stopped selling fruit and started his current business in the 20 de Julio square, in Barranquilla. He has been selling sportswear such as jerseys, pants, socks, accessories, key chains and flags since 2000 and, for him, this has been more profitable than his previous business in that market. Luis's business is located just outside one of Colombia's most important sports arena, the Metropolitano Stadium. He is the pioneer in his activity and works along with his wife (pictured by his side) for more than 12 hours a day, from Monday to Sunday. His clients are pedestrians, people referred to him and soccer fans, including from other stadiums in the country. He has a strong competition but he is able to stand out for being innovative, having good prices and diversifying the inventory he offers. He is currently asking for a loan in the amount of $1.300.000 to buy sports articles wholesale and in cash, especially the ones he offers such as souvenirs, jerseys of different teams, flags and accessories. His loans with the bank have always been aimed to increase the variety of his inventory. He has also at times used them to eliminate expensive debt with loan sharks. His main goal is to transition from being a street vendor to being a registered business owner and convert his business into wholesale. These are precisely his challenges.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sports articles wholesale and in cash, especially souvenirs, jerseys of different teams, flags and accessories

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es:
Luis Alberto es un padre de familia de 57 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a sus tres hijos en el distrito de Olmos, ubicado a una hora y cuarenta y cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace algunos años tiene un negocio de venta de todo tipo de artículos, accesorios y repuestos digitales, tales como celulares, cargadores, tarjetas prepago, carcasas entre otros. Su establecimiento queda ubicado en el marcado de la ciudad de Olmos , el se ha hecho conocido en el rubro y ya tiene una clientela fiel debido al tiempo que lleva funcionando, al buen trato y a la calidad de productos que ofrece.

El negocio es la única fuente de ingreso con la que cuenta por lo que Luis Alberto desea ampliarlo y así poder obtener ganancias que le faciliten otorgarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida. Por este motivo se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de más mercadería para implementar su negocio.

Luis Alberto es un padre de familia bastante responsable y que gusta mucho de la actividad que realiza. Su sueño es poder ampliar su negocio con la compra de productos más modernos y expandirse como empresario. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
Luis Alberto, 57, is the father of a family, living with his wife and three children in the Olmos district, located one hour 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For some years he has had a business selling all sorts of articles, accessories, and digital supplies such as cellular phones, chargers, prepaid cards, and cases among other things. His establishment is located in the market in the city of Olmos. He has become known in the area and already has a faithful clientele thanks to the time he has been in business, to his good service, and to the quality of products that he sells. The business is his sole income, so Luis Alberto wants to enlarge it to increase his earnings, allowing him to give his family a better quality of life. Therefore he is requesting a loan of $700 from Edpyme Alternativa that he plans to invest in the purchase of additional merchandise for his business. Luis Alberto is a responsible head of family who very much enjoys his business. His dream is to be able to enlarge his business by purchasing M. up-to-date products and thus grow as an entrepreneur. He has worked before with our institution and has shown responsibility and precise punctuality in his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of digital merchandise

loans.name: Muriel

texts.es:
Muriel J. G. tiene 40 años y vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos entre 19 y 9 años de edad en el barrio La Paz de Barranquilla, barrio conocido por sus fiestas religiosas como la fiesta de San Pedro y San Pablo, y sus procesiones de Semana Santa. Su negocio consiste en una mini tienda de víveres, como arroz, aceite, azúcar, leche, pan, sal y café, de productos domiciliarios como jabón y champú, y de una miscelánea. Inició su negocio hace 4 años cuando dejó de vender ropa bajo pedido y productos por catálogo. Siempre le ha gustado trabajar y quería empezar un negocio. Ahora cuenta con clientes como amigos, familiares y vecinos y va promocionando a sus casas para impulsar las ventas cuando tiene nuevos productos. Sin embargo, considera su mayor desafío la ubicación del negocio ya que no se ve desde fuera con falta de espacio y de capital. Para resolver esto su meta es de tener una tienda más grande en el primer cuarto que le otorgaría más espacio tanto a la tienda como a la vivienda y haría la tienda más visible en la calle.
Actualmente Muriel solicita un crédito de $2.000.000 la mitad quiere invertirlo en la compra de productos para el negocio; con la otra mitad quiere mejorar la vivienda en subir el techo que está bastante bajo. Aunque este es su segundo crédito, el esposo estuvo vinculado a la Fundación durante varios años y en aquella época los dos fueron surtiendo más, ganando más clientes y consiguiendo mayores ventas. Además, pudieron construir la cocina de su casa y otro cuarto en la vivienda. Más adelante, Muriel sueña con arreglar la casa por completo y también con educar a sus hijos para que terminen el bachillerato en el colegio, un paso que Muriel considera imprescindible para que hagan algo en la vida.
texts.en:
Muriel J. G. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and four children, who are between the ages of 9 and 19, in the neighborhood of La Paz in Barranquilla. This neighborhood is known for its religious festivals, such as the Festival of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, and the Holy Week processions.

Muriel’s business consists of a mini-grocery store where she sells rice, oil, sugar, milk, bread, salt, and coffee. She also has household products in stock such as soap, shampoo, and other items. Muriel started her store four years ago when she quit her clothing by catalog order business. She always enjoyed working and wanted to start another business. Now her customers include her friends, relatives, and neighbors. She goes to their homes to boost her sales by advertising whenever she has new products. However, she considers her greatest challenges to be the location of her business because it is not visible from the outside, the lack of space, and insufficient capital. To resolve these issues, her goal is to have a larger store in her main room that provides more space and is more visible from the street.

Muriel is currently requesting a loan of 2,000,000 COP. Half of the money will be invested in the purchase of products for her business. The other half will be used to improve her home by raising the ceiling because it is quite low. Although this is her second loan, her husband has been associated with the Foundation for several years. During this season, the two of them plan to acquire more supplies, attract more customers, and continue making more sales. In addition, they hope to build a kitchen and add another room to their home. Later on, Muriel dreams of completely remodeling her house and also providing her children with an education so that they can finish both high school and college. She considers this to be an essential step to doing something in life.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products for her business & raise the ceiling of her house

loans.name: Bertilda Isabel

texts.es:
Bertilda Isabel A. Gutiérrez tiene 46 años y vive en Barranquilla en El Pueblo, barrio popular, alegre y rumbero en el sur occidente de la ciudad y tristemente conocido por inundaciones en tiempos de lluvia. Está casada con tres hijos de los cuales los menores son un hijo de 17 años de edad y una hija de 8. Bertilda se dedica a la elaboración de pasabocas como deditos y empanaditas; los deditos más grandes los vende en tiendas y los más pequeños se los encarga a la gente para fiestas y otros eventos. Ahora solicita un crédito por valor de $ 1.800.000, para comprar materias primas e  insumos como harina de trigo, aceite, azucar y queso, con los que espera ampliar su negocio y buscar más tiendas y colegios para distribuir sus productos.
Bertilda inició el negocio hace 8 años cuando se mudó de la casa de su suegra en otro barrio y se instaló en El Pueblo. Aprendió de su mamá, “mujer que “sabe hacer todo” y se lo enseñó a sus hijos, y cuando tuvo que apoyar a su esposo, recurrió a la elaboración de pasabocas. Su esposo distribuye a domicilio y a veces la ayuda a llevar los productos donde los clientes de ella. Está vinculada a la Fundación  hace alrededor de 4 años y manifiesta que económicamente está mejor porque ha ido adecuando su casa: arregló la cocina poniendo baldosas en el piso y considera esto muy influyente en el negocio, pues es más higiénico y  atrae a más clientes. Dice que su mayor desafío es la falta de capital y se acuerda que en algún momento tuvo la oportunidad de vender sus productos a casinos, pero no tenía capital en ese entonces y no pudo. A pesar de las bajas ventas en esta temporada, sabe que todo se incrementa más a partir de los siguientes meses. Quiere conseguir más clientes para salir adelante y realizar el sueño  de ayudar a  sus hijos a que sean profesionales para que vivan mejor.
texts.en:
Bertilda Isabel A. Gutiérrez, 46, lives in Barranquilla’s El Pueblo neighborhood, a popular, cheerful, high-spirited neighborhood in the southwestern part of the city which, sadly, is infamous due to flooding during the rainy season. She is married and has three children, the youngest of whom are a 17-year-old son and an 8-year-old daughter. Bertilda makes snacks like deditos (little finger-shaped pastries) and turnovers. She sells the larger deditos in stores and the smaller ones are ordered by people for parties and other special events. She is asking for a $1.800.000 loan to buy ingredients like wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and cheese so that she can increase production and add more stores and schools to her distribution points list. Bertilda started her business 8 years ago when she moved from her mother-in-law’s house to a different neighborhood, El Pueblo. She learned from her mother, “a woman who knows how to do everything,” and passed it on to her children. When the need arose to help her husband with household expenses, she turned to the manufacture of snacks. Her husband delivers door-to-door and sometimes helps her take the product to her customers. She has been associated with the Fundación for about 4 years and she states that she is better off financially because she’s been able to improve her house: she tiled the kitchen floor and considers this to be very important to her business because it’s more hygienic and attracts more customers. She says that her greatest challenge is the lack of capital and remembers that there was a time when she had the opportunity to sell her products to casinos but lack of capital then kept her from doing so. Despite drop in sales during this season, she knows that everything will improve the next few months. She wants to attract more customers in order to progress and reach her goal of helping her children become professionals so that they can live better.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and cheese.

loans.name: Sarwari Begum's Group

texts.en:
Sarwari Begum is the wife of A. H. and lives in the city of Vehari in Pakistan. She is the mother of eight children – five daughters and three sons. Her five daughters are enrolled in a local school while her two sons work in a factory for a monthly wage. Her husband runs a cold drinks corner in the food market.
Sarwari is a very nice woman. She owns and operates a sewing business. She sews clothes for women in her community and charges them different rates – for example, for designer clothes she charges 150 PKR and for simple stitching she charges 100 PKR. Her income allows her to share the financial burden with her husband.
Sarwari has successfully repaid her first loan to Asasah, a microfinance institutition in Pakistan and Kiva partner. Now she is requesting another loan to expand her husband’s cold drinks corner by buying cold drinks in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cold drinks in bulk

loans.name: Armando

texts.es:
Armando es un padre de familia de 44 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a sus tres hijos en el caserío Laguna Chica, una zona rural del distrito de Olmos, en la provincia Lambayeque, ubicado a dos horas y quince minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace varios años se dedica a la venta informal de gasolina, el posee galones de gasolina en su vivenda y los ofrece en venta a sus vecinos que los necesitan para alimentar los motores con los que extraen agua de pozos para irrigar sus cultivos, este negocio es una fuente importante de ingreso económico para su familia, ya que su actividad principal es la agricultura pero esta no le provee de ingresos económicos permanentes.

El negocio goza de mucha acogida ya que los caseríos del distrito de Olmos quedan alejados entre si y alejados de la ciudad, por lo que no tienen acceso facil a un grifo que les brinde el combustible que necesitan. Armando se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la ampliación de negocio con la compra de más gasolina.

Su sueño es poder ampliar su negocio para poder abastacer a la zona en donde vive y a los caseríos cercanos. El es un padre responsable y honrado. En su comunidad es muy respetado, actualmente tiene el cargo de Teniente Gobernador de lugar, un cargo representativo ante las autoridades del distrito. Por otro lado el ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Armando is a 44 year old father who lives with his wife and three children in the village of Laguna Chica, a rural area in the District of Olmos, Lambayeque Province. This community is located two hours and fifteen minutes away from the city of Chiclayo.

Armando has been selling gasoline informally for several years. He stores gallons of gasoline at his home and offers it for sale to his neighbors who need to refuel their motors used for drawing well water to irrigate their crops. This business is an important source of income for his family. His main business activity is farming, but it does not provide a steady source of income.

This business has been well-received in the villages of the District of Olmos that are located far from the city and do not have easy access to tap water. He provides the fuel that is needed. Armando is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 2000 PEN to invest in the expansion of his business by purchasing more gasoline.

His dream is to increase his business buy supplying the area where he lives and the nearby villages. Armando is a responsible and honest father. He is well-respected in his community because he currently serves as the local Lieutenant Governor, a position that reports to the district authorities. Armando has worked previously worked our Institution and has demonstrated responsibility and punctuality when completing his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase gasoline

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Salma is the wife of A. L. and lives in the mid-sized city of Vehari in Pakistan. She owns a two-roomed brick house in which she has lived with her family for the past 22 years. She has nine children – four daughters and five sons. Her first three sons work in different barber shops for a monthly wage. The others are enrolled in a local school. Her husband owns and operates a tea stall in the food market where he also serves his customers with food items (biscuits and chips). He has been in this business for over five years.
Salma is a very skillful lady. She operates an embroidery business. She collects order from clothes shops and earns a profit after completing each embroidered dress. She uses her income to pay for utilities, but she also saves part of her income for her elder son's marriage, which will be held in December this year.
Salma has successfully repaid her first loan to Kiva partner, Asasah (a microfinance institution of Pakistan). Now she is requesting another loan for her husband to purchase items for his business such as milk, sugar, tea cups etc. in order to generate a good profit.

loans.use: To buy items for tea stall such as milk, sugar, teacups etc.

loans.name: Sylvia Lorena

texts.es:
Este Sra. Se llama Sylvia Lorena G. Rivera, tiene 30 años de edad, casado, es maestra Escuela Primaria de una comunidad Rural que se llama los laureles, tiene una hija, la que está cursando la escuela primaría.

Con nuestra institución ha obtenido la cantidad de cuatro créditos, los que le han servido para realizar gastos personales y este último para mejorar su vivienda, vale mencionar que en los tres créditos otorgados anteriormente ha sido muy responsable con sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
This is Sylvia. She is 30 years old, is married and she teaches elementary school in a rural community called "Los Laureles." She has a daughter attending elementary school. She has gotten four loans through our institution and has used the money for personal expenses and the latest to make improvements to her home. She has been very timely in repaying her previous loans.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building materials

loans.name: Julian

texts.es:
Julián P. es un señor de 39 años de edad el cual vive con su esposa y tres hijas en una comunidad llamada Santa Fe localizada en Los Chiles, provincia de Alajuela; está comunidad se destaca por ser una zona montañosa y por estar muy cerca de la frontera norte de nuestro país. Sus principales actividades económicas son la ganadería y la agricultura específicamente se da la siembra de granos básicos, caña de azúcar, naranja

Don Julián   desde hace algunos años inicio su propio negocio una pulpería (tiendita de abarrotes) para vender productos básicos a sus vecinos en su propia casa; pero la demanda lo ha obliga a construir un nuevo local. Asegura que con este negocio ha logrado tener  una actividad económica rentable que la ayuda a mejorar su calidad de vida. 

Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por ¢665000(seiscientos sesenta y  cinco mil colones) para comprar mercadería que necesito en su negocio y el material necesario para su nuevo local. De esta manera el podrá continuar con su negocio. Don Johnny  comenta que el servicio que el  brinda es muy importante ya que no existe otra pulpería cercana a esa zona  por lo tanto comenta que tiene bastantes clientes. 


Don Julian es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Manantial de Santa Fe, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer  préstamo y con él espera crecer más a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito muchas personas se pueden superar de manera digna y honesta.
texts.en:
Julián P. is a 39 years old gentleman who lives with his wife and three daughters in a community called Santa Fe, which is located in Los Chiles, Alajuela Province. The community is situated in a mountainous area near the northern border of the country. The main economic activities are ranching and farming, with specific emphasis on the cultivation of grains, sugar cane, and oranges.

A few years ago Don Julián started his own grocery business where he sells basic products to his neighbors from his home. Due to demand, he is forced to build a new location. He is assured that this business has achieved profitable activity that will help improve his quality of life.

Don Julián is currently requesting a loan of 665,000 CRC in order to buy merchandise that he needs for his business and the necessary materials for his new location. This will enable him to continue with his business. Don Julián says that that the service he provides is very important because there are no other grocery stores near this area. He also indicates that he has enough customers.

Don Julián is a member of the Manantial de Santa Fe Communal Credit Enterprise, one of 100 member organizations that make up EDESA in Costa Rica. This is his first loan and he hopes to grow personally and financially. He also thanks these type of organizations and other credit facilitators that help many people to excel in a dignified and honest manner.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise & build a new location

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
Francisco G. G. es un señor de 39 años de edad el cual vive con su esposa y su hijo en una comunidad llamada Santa Fe localizada en Los Chiles, provincia de Alajuela; está comunidad se destaca por ser una zona montañosa y por estar muy cerca de la frontera norte de nuestro país. Sus principales actividades económicas son la ganadería y la agricultura específicamente se da la siembra de granos básicos, caña de azúcar, naranja.

Don Francisco   se ha dedicado desde muy joven a la agricultura, especialmente se ha interesado en el engorde de cerdos para su venta, , ya que es una forma de generar ingresos para su familia. Dice estar muy contento porque gracias a las ganancias que ha obtenido va a poder arreglar su ya que se encuentra en muy mal estado.

El  desea obtener un micro crédito por un monto de ¢617000 (seiscientos diecisiete mil colones) para comprar más cerdos y mejorar las condiciones de cuido, Y así aumentar la producción. El sabe que contar con más cerdos es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo; pero dice que así podrá fortalecer más su proyecto para llegar  a ser un microempresario exitoso.

Don Francisco es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Manantial de Santa Fe, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su segundo  préstamo y con él espera crecer más a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
Francisco G. G. is a 39 year old gentleman who lives with his wife and child in a community called Santa Fe, which is located in Los Chiles, Alajuela Province. The community is situated in a mountainous area near the northern border of the country. The main economic activities are ranching and farming, with specific emphasis on the cultivation of grains, sugar cane, and oranges. Don Francisco has been engaged in farming since a very young age. He has been especially interested in fattening pigs to sell so that he can generate income for his family. Don Francisco says he is very happy with the gains he has made because he will be able to renovate his house because it is in very bad condition. He wants to obtain a microloan in the amount of 665,000 CRC to purchase more pigs and improve the conditions for raising them, thereby increasing his production. He know that having more pigs is a greater sacrifice and demands more work, but doing so will strengthen his business so that he can become a successful micro-entrepreneur. Don Francisco is a member of the Manantial de Santa Fe Communal Credit Enterprise, one of 100 member organizations that make up EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be his second loan and he hopes to grow more on a personal and financial level. He also says that he is thankful for these types of organizations and credit facilitators who dedicate more time to productive activities.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pigs & rebuild a pig pen

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
Maria Isabel A. Araya es un señora  de 47 años de edad quien vive con su esposa e hija  en una pequeña comunidad llamada La Trinchera de Pital localizada en la provincia de Alajuela; cuyas principales actividades productivas son la ganadería y la agricultura, donde destaca el cultivo de la piña; siendo estas comercializadas principalmente en los mercados internacionales.  Por esta razón, el desarrollo de la comunidad ha venido creciendo en los últimos años generando una mayor demanda de productos y servicios brindando mayores oportunidades de trabajo.

Doña María se dedica a la agricultura, en estos momentos ella se dedica a la siembra de yuca, un tubérculo de agradable sabor, rico en nutrientes, de procesamiento agroindustrial amplio y de gran demanda tanto en Costa Rica como en otros países.

Actualmente doña María está solicitando un préstamo de ¢600000 (seiscientos mil colones), para ampliar su siembra y así ayudarse con  la preparación del suelo, compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos entre otros insumos que sean necesarios para garantizar la siembra óptima del ñame. 
Con esta inversión  espera lograr una buena cosecha, con un producto de características apropiadas para conseguir un precio de venta alto. Con esto desea iniciar un proyecto exitoso que le permita mejorar las condiciones de su familia.


Ella es socia de la Empresa Comunal de Mujeres al Éxito de la Trinchera de Pital, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica.
