loans.use: To add her savings to build her house

loans.name: Myrna's Group

texts.en:
Myrna Q. is from Calao East, Santiago, Isabela. She is thirty-nine years old. Myrna is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Myrna Q.'s group.

Myrna is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a business venture in the arts sector operating a handicraft business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty handicrafts to tourists and local community members. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. This will be Myrna's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-nine branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing merchandise stock

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl C. is from the village of Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is twenty-eight years old. Sheryl is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Sheryl owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Sheryl has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Sheryl joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheryl is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Sheryl's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-nine branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en: Kiden S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. Kiden is 41 years old and is widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children’s school fees. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Sophak

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophak C. and her husband, Mr. Savit Uk, have been married since 1991 and have five sons. One of them is a carpenter, two attend school and the other two are still young. The family lives along National Road Number One about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her husband has been driving a motorcycle taxi for more than six years.

Sophak has been selling corn for more than eight years and she sells mangoes as well.She hopes to continue to expand her business, so she is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase mangoes under contract to sell.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes under contract to sell

loans.name: Temeke Mikoroshini Group

texts.en:
Hawa Abraham age thirty-four, is married with three children, eighteen, twelve, and six years old. She has two businesses: a salon and a clothing shop, which she has operated for three years now. She works from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily, and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $111.

This will be Hawa’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first loan to buy equipment for her salon. She hopes now for a loan to increase her stock in her clothing shop. 

Hawa will share this loan with her loan group, Temeke Mikoroshini, which consists of eighteen members. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Hawa is in front in a black t-shirt.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for sale in her shop.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Heng P. and his wife, Mrs. Seng Veng, were married in 1979 and have six children: one son and five daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker and the young son attends school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mr. Heng P. has been a fisherman for more than thirty years and his wife sells the fish as well as vegetables in Takhmao market.

Mr. Heng P. has obtained previous Kiva loans; he is now asking for another loan of $1,000 to build a concrete room under his wooden house. He will also use a part of his loan to continue his fishing business by purchasing bamboo to make more fishing materials.

loans.use: To build a concrete room under his wooden house and to buy bamboo for his fishing business

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun A., 53 years old (in the picture), and her husband, Mr. Choem Cheav, 49 years old, have been married since 1986 and have one son and two daughters. One of her daughters is married, but lives in the family home and the other two are in school. They live in a small village along National Road Number Five, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  

Mrs. Sokhoen A. just started a business of producing hammocks, while her husband has been selling piglets for more than thirty years. She is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for her son-in-law to carry sugar palm to sell. She also will use a part of her loan to help provide capital for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son-in-law to carry sugar palm to sell.

loans.name: Mt Udzungwa Group

texts.en:
Asha S., is a sixty-year-old widow with one son and many grandchildren. She sells samosas at a school called Goba, which she has done for five years  now. She works from 5 a.m. to after midday, and she is able to make monthly profit of about $60.

This will be Asha’s sixth loan from Tujijenge, Tanzania. She used the previous loan to make more samosas, and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to increase her materials to make samosas.

Asha will share this loan with her subgroup A, of Mt. Udzungwa Group, which has six members. The other members deal in selling books, motorcycle spare tires, Animals, water, soda, juice, and have shops. The members of the group hold each other accountable for repaying the loan. 

In the picture, Asha is the only woman.

loans.use: To increase the materials for making samosas.

loans.name: Se

texts.en:
Mr. Se Y., 32 (pictured with his son) and his wife, Mrs. Koeun Hul, 30, have been remarried for ten years and have two children: one daughter, who attends school; and one young son. They live in a village along National Road Number Five, approximately seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Se is a blacksmith, while his wife has been a garment factory worker for twelve years. He wants to buy a motorcycle for commuting because he does not have any means of transportation. Hence, he is asking for a loan of $500 to make the purchase.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike commuting for commuting.

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa E. (in the photo) and her husband Mr. Chhorn Cheng, live on an Island of Mekong River, about fifteen kilometres from Phnom Penh, were married in 1988 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Channa has been a silk weaver for more than twenty years, a skill she learned from her mother. She also started a new business selling silk products. She buys silk fabrics from weavers in her village and transports them to sell in other provinces far away from her house. Her husband has been a construction worker since 1993.

Mrs. Channa has received loans from Kiva before, and is now requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Diane

texts.en:
Diane is 28 years old and married with two children who are 2 and 6 years old.  Diane has been a self-employed businesswoman selling clothing items. She sells mainly fabric for clothes and some other items needed in sewing various styles of clothes.  She has been in this business for about two years and the hours of her business are from 7 am to 7 pm every day.

Diane is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can expand her business by adding more clothing items for sale. Hopefully this will allow her to satisfy the demands of her customers.  Through this satisfaction, Diane hopes to start saving for her future as well as reinvesting in her business via the use of the earned profits.  In addition, she will send her child, who is of school age, to a better school.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach S. was born in 1971 and resides with other family members in Siem Reap Province. She owns a medium-sized grocery store where she sells many articles to earn a living. She sells items such as cooked ingredients, soft drinks, canned foods and some snack foods for kids. She earns around $6 a day to contribute to her family's living expenses. She is married to Not Savy, 37, a local statue carver. He owns a handicraft shop and has employees to provide service. The couple has three children who are students and under their care. Lach S. is applying for a loan to resupply her stock, increasing various inventory items in order to better meet her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To increase various inventory items

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en:
Donathile is 35 years old, married with a three-year-old child and she takes care of three dependents, ages 3, 6 and 8 years old.  Donathile struggles by selling a variety of goods in her shop as her photo indicates.  Those goods include cosmetic goods and drinks.  She has been in this business for about three years and the hours of her business are from 6 am until late in the evening.

Donathile realized which items the people from her business area are interested in buying so she wants to put her energy into selling those drinks which are more profitable.  In addition, she wants also to start wholesaling to the retailers.  In doing so, Donathile will hopefully earn more profit, which in turn will allow her to build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and drinks.

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene is 32 years old and he is still single.  Eugene is known in the business of selling a variety of clothes, mainly jeans, and this is his fifteenth successful year in this business.  The hours of his business are from 6 am to 7 pm every day.

Eugene is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by adding a variety of styles such as shirts and some other attractive styles.  With this additional business, Eugene will hopefully earn more profits than his previous business.  With these profits, one portion will be used to build a secure future for his future family as he is in the process of getting engaged to be married. The other portion of his profits will be reinvested in his business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes especially jeans for sale

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is 28 years old and he is still single.  Jean Baptiste is known for selling women's clothes. This is his third successful year in this business, which he runs from 8 am to 8 pm every day.

Jean Baptiste is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by adding a variety of styles such as clothes for men and children.  With this additional business, he hopes to earn more profit than his previous business.  With these profits, one portion will be used to build a secure future for his future family. (He is getting engaged to be married.) The rest of the profits will be reinvested in his business.

loans.use: To buy men's and children's clothes to sell

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Mrs. Lang L. (pictured with her husband) and her husband, Mr. Sophorn Horn, live in a small village across from the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1988 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of them attend school and one weaves silk at home. 

Mrs. Lang L. has been a silk weaver for 5 years. She sells her finished products to middlemen in the village, who then take them to sell at the Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been building wooden houses for 5 years as well. Besides these businesses, the couple also grows rice on their rice farm near the village.

Mrs. Lang has received a loan from Kiva before, and is now requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 26 years old and he is still single.  Jean de Dieu owns a grocery store and this is his second successful year in this business. His business is open from early in the morning until late in the evening every day.

Although Jean de Dieu has been in this business for about two years, his original investment is still too low to earn enough profit from his sales.  To end this, Jean de Dieu is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that he can add cakes, cookies, and some other pastries.  In addition, he will sell foodstuffs like rice, different types of flour, sugar etc.  With this expansion, Jean de Dieu will be able to continue his life with a successful business.  The savings from additional profits that are not reinvested in his business will allow him to build his future.

loans.use: To purchase cakes, cookies, and some other pastries to resell

loans.name: Sokly

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokly K. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Rithy Moeung, live on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, were married in 2000, and have two sons. One is in school and the other is still too young. 

Sokly has been weaving silk since she was sixteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She also started new business selling silk products. She buys silk fabrics from weavers in her village and transports them to sell in other provinces far away from her house. Sokly has had a Kiva loan in the past, and is now requesting another loan of US$500 to purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Sifa is 31 years old and is still single. She is a proven entrepreneur selling a variety of products in her shop including cosmetics products, body lotion, toothpaste, notebooks and foodstuffs, mainly Irish potatoes, etc. She has been in this business for about a year.

Sifa needs a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by adding a large quantity of foodstuffs as they are in high demand by a number of her customers. With this additional large quantity of foodstuffs for sale, Sifa hopes to increase her sales as well as the profits, which in turn will allow her to start saving for her future and reinvesting in her business.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Mrs. Kosal I. (in the picture), is a widow with two sons. One of her sons is an electrician and the other one weaves silk at home. She lives on an island on the Mekong River approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Kosal has been a silk weaver since she was 20 years old. Previously, she was part of a group loan that included two families and she was the group leader. Now she is asking for another individual loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange is 29 and is still single. She is known as a nurse and she provides medical services to the people from her area. She employs four nurses in her small dispensary who work in shifts to cover the full 24 hours.

Solange has an idea of expanding her small dispensary by adding two rooms so that she may cater to a larger number of clients. Apart from adding those two rooms, she will also try to renovate the existing rooms by painting them.

To end this, Solange needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. If successful, she hopes to provide a better service to her clients and, hopefully, her profits will be increased.

loans.use: To add two more rooms and renovate the existing ones

loans.name: Jimmy's Group

texts.en:
Jimmy O. is from the village of Brgy.Nalubbunan, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 41 years old. Jimmy is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jimmy is married and has 2 school-aged children. He owns and operates a motorcycle transport business. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a tricycle transport service. Jimmy has been involved in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2007, Jimmy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jimmy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Jimmy is requesting a new loan, his eighth, for 11,000 PHP, which will be used to help purchase a new motorcycle unit. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a new transport unit

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 41 years old and is married with three children who are 6, 7 and 11 years old.

Jean de Dieu is known as a self-employed businessman selling bread, cosmetics products, and other types of goods as the photo indicates. He has been in this business for about five years and the hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Although Jean de Dieu has been in this business for about five years, his seed money is still too low to earn sufficient profits. Better profits could be used for further reinvestment in his business, thus improving his family situation and saving for a better future.

To fix this situation, Jean de Dieu is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which hopefully will help him to achieve a lot via his business.

loans.use: To purchase bread, cosmetics products and another goods to expand his business

loans.name: Godelive

texts.en:
Godelive is 37 years old and she is married. She is a mother who is poor and struggles by selling some goods in her small shop so that she can buy her daily food. She has been in this business for ten years but, unfortunately, she has no savings from her business. The hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Godelive is now requesting a Kiva loan so that she can expand her shop by adding enough cosmetics goods, foodstuffs like sugar, rice and different types of flour, and some other goods which seem to be in high demand in her business area.

With this loan, Godelive hopes to earn more profits than her simple previous business. If successful, she will start saving as well as improving her family situation.

loans.use: To add more cosmetics goods and foodstuffs like sugar, rice and different types of flour

loans.name: Faustin

texts.en:
Faustin is 33 years old and is married with one kid who is 1 year old.

Faustin is commonly known in the business of selling a variety of jewelry, as his photo indicates. This is his fourth successful year in this business, which he operates from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Faustin is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to improve his business. In addition, he wants to start another source of income by selling soft drinks, which hopefully will increase his revenue.

Faustin has a vision of keeping his businesses sustainable through reinvesting more in them.

loans.use: To buy additional jewelry and also soft drinks as another business

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en:
Epiphanie is 37 years old and is married with three children who are 2, 5 and 7 years old. She also takes care of two relatives who are 11 and 14 years old.

Epiphanie is a self-employed businesswoman selling a variety of goods, as her photo indicates. Those goods include cosmetics products like body lotion and toothpaste as well as foodstuffs like rice, sugar, flour and cooking oil. Her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Epiphanie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her shop by purchasing a large quantity of sugar and rice, as they are in high demand.

With this large quantity, she will also start wholesaling. In doing so, she hopes to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow her to renovate her house, continue paying school fees for her two relatives, as well as build a secure future for her three children.

loans.use: To expand her shop by purchasing a large quantity of sugar and rice

loans.name: Ngeang

texts.en: Ngeang T. Y., 53, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She and her husband sell various kinds of groceries on the boat for a gross income of about USD 25 per day.  T. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to fix her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Rou

texts.en:
Rou S., 24, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She is employed in a local garment factory and makes an income of about USD 2.50 per day. Her husband produces stoves made from clay, earning an income of USD 5.00 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to start a new business and generate a better income.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Isatu K. is 42 years old, married, with four children, three girls and one boy. The eldest is working, the second one is in secondary school, and the youngest is in primary school. She sells provisions and coal in Wilberforco, very close to the market, where she stays with her family.

She has been a LAPO, SL client for almost 2 years now, and has taken out three previous loans, which she used to invest in the same type of busness as provisions and coal. She then used the profits to take care of her family. Isatu is asking for a new loan of 2,000,000 Leones from LAPO, SL. With the help of Kiva lenders, she will be able to improve her busness and assist her husband in taking care of the family.

loans.use: This loan will be used to pay for provisions and coal.

loans.name: Korn

texts.en:
Korn S., 43, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She is a housewife, while her husband is a motorbike repairman, earning an income of USD 5.20 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase motorbike spare parts for her husband to expand his current business and generate a better income. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for resale.

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Chhem S. is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She has a business of tailoring, which provides an income of about USD 2.00 per day. Her husband runs a business of cleaning cars and motorbikes, earning an income of USD 13.00 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to build a bigger place to clean the cars and motorbikes. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To build a bigger place to clean the cars and motorbikes.

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van S., 45, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She and her husband have a business of collecting palm juice to produce palm sugar, which provides an income of about USD 6.00 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached to transport clay products to sell in other provinces. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a trailer attached.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophea Sem Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twenty-two people are part of a village bank loan, and they all live in Chanlak village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sophea S. is the village bank president, and was selected by all the members. The group members will use the loan for different purposes. She is a vegetable seller in the market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Sophea S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables for reselling. Her husband, Mr. Pech Rous, is a farmer who rents a plot of land to cultivate rice to support his family. Through this activity, the couple supports two children, who are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for re-selling.

loans.name: Obama Group

texts.en:
Saraya Salum, 43, is married with three children, ages 22, 22 and 14. She has had a grocery store and hotel since 1984. She works from 8 a.m. to midnight and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $652.

This will be Saraya’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first loan to improve the hotel and has repaid the loan successfully. She hopes for a loan to start selling water, juice and sodas at wholesale prices. 

Saraya will share this loan with her loan group, Obama, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Saraya is in front in a black and white dress.

loans.use: to start selling water, juice and sodas at wholesale prices

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong V., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She has a business of selling chairs and tables made from cement, which provides an income of about USD 3.00 per day. Her husband is a village clerk, who earns an income of USD 50 per month.

V. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase more cement chairs and tables. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cement chairs and tables for sale.

loans.name: Yesjan

texts.en:
Yesjan is 25 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. His family live together with Yesjan's parents in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Presently, he operates a manufacturing Kazakh souvenir and instrument business in his town. Yesjan makes Kazakh traditional instruments called dombra, and other souvenirs to sell. He started his business in 2001, when he learned how to manufacture Kazakh traditional instruments and souvenirs from his father. Yesjan has steadily expanded his business, and gained valuable experience in previous years.

Nowadays, his working capital exceeds 300,000 tugrugs. He sells 5-6 dombras per week for 20,000 tugrugs. Furthermore, he has a loyal customer base because of his well-designed and high quality products. Yesjan has been planning to expand his production line and will use a variety of materials, including iron, for his products in the future. He is a very hardworking person who has great communication skills. Yesjan is requesting a 800,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of materials for the upcoming month when demand for dombras is very high.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo R., 57, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She sells corn and Cambodian traditional cakes for an income of about USD 10.00 per day. Her husband is a private security guard, earning an income of USD 1.50 per day.

R. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to repair the house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling.  This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair the house.

loans.name: Sokhoen's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has four people in it, and they all live in Preak Traeng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sokhoen C. is a group leader, who has been selected by all the members. Each group member will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. C. is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice to supporting her family.

She has a problem with her rice field, as it is infertile and far from an irrigation system. Thus, Mrs. Sokhoen C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and rest of the loan she would like to use to hire farmer laborers to plow the rice field. Her husband is a construction worker. Through this activity, the couple supports five children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is too young to work or go to school, and the others attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline.

loans.name: Yoy

texts.en:
Yoy M., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She is a housewife, while her husband is a taxi driver who operates transportation from his province to the city, earning an income of about USD 25 per day.

M. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a new car to attract more clients to his service. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. (M.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy a new car for her husband's business.

loans.name: Tuul

texts.en:
Tuul is 53 years old and lives with his wife in Tuv province, Mongolia in an apartment which they own. He has two sons, the oldest of which is 28 years old and works as a specialist for a mining company. His youngest son, Purevochir, is 26 years old, and has been working in Japan for the last two years.

Tuul operates a taxi service business in his home town. He previously worked as a driver for a local organization between 1977-2003, but has operated independently since 2003. He has steadily made progress with his business over the years and is known today as an experienced and safe driver. Tuul uses his earnings to support his family and has to pay for repairs to his car regularly. Tuul is a very hardworking person and is optimistic about the future. He says, “My dream is to one day start my own auto repair center.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to overhaul his car.

loans.use: To repair his car.

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny S. is 32 years old and a resident of Siem Reap province, where she and her husband earn a living by fishing in and around the river. They are able to generate $5 each day to take care of their family. Ny S. has four school-aged children, all of whom assist with their parents' business when they are not studying. Recently some of their fishing accessories broke down and the family’s income has been affected. Because Ny S. doesn’t have money, she requested a loan from HKL, a Kiva partner. Ny S. will be using her loan to buy new sets of fishing tools to increase the quantity of fish she catches.

loans.use: To buy new sets of fishing tools

loans.name: Erdenechuluun

texts.en:
Erdenechuluun is 40 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a house which belongs to his parents. His two children, ages 18 and 11, both attend a local secondary school.

Erdenechuluun operates an auto repair and spare parts trading business in his town. He gained experience in his business by previously working in Japan between 2004 and 2009. He helped his brother import Japanese jeep tires to sell back home in Mongolia. Since coming back to Mongolia and starting his own business, he has worked hard to establish himself and support his family. Erdenechuluun has made quick progress over the last year and attributes his success to his good communication skills. He is optimistic about the future and says, “I would like to expand my business and improve my family's quality of life.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more jeep tires from Japan for his auto parts business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts.

loans.name: Bou

texts.en: Bou S., 29, is widowed and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She is employed in a local garment factory for an income of about USD 2.5 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 200 to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to pay for her children’s school. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Kaseso Group

texts.en:
Pilly Y., age 36, is married with two children ages 12 and 4 years. She has a general store business which started 6 years ago. She works from 6am to 10pm daily and she is able to make monthly profits of about $148.

This will be Pilly’s 1st loan from Tujijenge, Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to start selling drinks like beers.

Pilly will share this loan with her loan Group Kosese which totals 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Pilly is in the orange dress. 1st from left second row

loans.use: To start selling different drinks like beers.

loans.name: Kurimbai

texts.en: Kurimbai is 33 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest son and daughter currently attend secondary school and his youngest daughter hasn't yet reached school age. His wife, Nina, is currently unemployed due to a disability. Kurimbai operates a meat trading business at the local market in his town. He provides a variety of fresh meat products, such as mutton and goat meat, to his many customers. Kurimbai started his business in 1997, and has successfully expanded and grown his operation over the years. He has also gained a lot of business experience. Kurimbai is a very hard working person and has many plans for the future. He would like to build a large house for his family. He is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~ 422 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of meat while wholesale prices are low.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep T., 65, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products. She is a housewife and her husband is a barber, earning an income of USD 7 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to construct a roof of their house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to expand her husband’s barber shop. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To build a roof on their house

loans.name: Melonne

texts.fr: A. Melonne est née le 19 juin 1968 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Cela fait bientôt cinq ans que Melonne vit à Abomey Calavi, au Bénin. Mariée à TOHON Sosthène, un chaffeur, Melonne est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Melonne a encore trois autres enfants à sa charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec les enfants. Melonne et son mari supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour contribuer aux dépenses, Melonne gère un salon de coiffure à son domicile et par la même occasion y vend des mèches. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Melonne se procure les produits dont elle a besoin pour le bon fonctionnement de son salon.  Melonne exerce cette activité depuis huit ans environs et a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Melonne désire agrandir davantage son salon de coiffure et renforcer ses outils de travail, afin de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Adoukounou Melonne was born June 19, 1968 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. It is almost 5 years since Melonne has been living in Abomey Calavi, in Benin. Married to Tohon Sosthene, a driver, Melonne is the mother of two children all in school. Melonne has 3 more other children at her care. The couple live together with the children. Together, Melonne and her husband bear the expenses of the family. To contribute to the family expenses, Melonne runs a hairdressing salon at home and sells hair extensions in the salon through the same opportunity. It is in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin that Melonne gets the products that she needs for the smooth running of her salon. Melonne has been doing this business for about eight years and has already got a loan from ALIDe that she repaid. Melonne wants to extend more her hairdressing salon and to beef up her working tools in order to meet the demands of her customers. This makes her to request a second loan.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of  beauty products and hair extensions

loans.name: Los

texts.en:
Los V., 24, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products.

She sells sugar cane juice for an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Her husband operates his motorbike with a trailer attached to provide transportation services, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day.

V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase groceries for sale to add to her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to pay for her children’s school. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia

loans.use: To buy groceries to stock her store.

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Khem S., 27, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products.

She is employed in a local garment factory for an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Her husband provides transportation services to workers in the factory, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day. (S.'s husband is pictured.)

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband because the old one often needs repairs.

In the future she would like to use any additional profit to pay for her children’s school. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
Sor S., 30, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for fishing and palm products.

She rents video CDs to people in her village for an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Her husband buys and sells cows, earning an income of USD 5 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase cows for sale when the price is good.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to pay for her children’s school. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows for resale.

loans.name: Seyilbubu's Group

texts.en:
Today it is quite easy to meet people who complain about current economic situations and just refuse to seek solutions for their own problems, blaming everything around.

Nevertheless, the heroes of our story would consider everything said above as just an absence of creativity. Their principle is to be creative and keep on trying.

Seyilbubu O. is the leader of this group. By the age of 52 she had raised 4 sons. Seyilbubu is divorced and she successfully overcame the ordeal of being a sole provider for the family as her eldest son is married already and started to help support his family.

As to Seyilbubu’s occupation, she offers seamstress’s services. She makes handycrafts to order. She used to produce handycrafts for domestic use only. However, afterwards she started receiving orders from her acquaintances.

This activity has allowed her to lead a relatively independent life. Her monthly income amounts to about 60 USD. She thriftily saved money and was able to send her kids to school and provide them with school supplies and clothes.

Now Seyilbubu dreams about buying new household appliances and a new sewing machine. Before doing that she needs to make new handycrafts for sale. She is in need of a loan to purchase a hundred kg of wadding and fabric.

Seyilbubu’s partners are:

Bermet M., 39, is a mother of three children. Her husband works in construction. Bermet breeds cattle. Two of her children go to school. Bermet needs a loan to buy a cow. Bermet’s dream is to provide her children with education.

Gulnaz B., 34, has three children. Her eldest son, in spite of being just sixteen, already earns his own living. The other two children go to school. Gulnaz is a seamstress. She needs a loan to purchase fabric.

Ainura E. K., 41, breeds cattle and sells milk. Her husband is a policeman. He works in a crime detection department. In his free time he helps his wife look after the cattle. Ainura hopes to obtain this loan and buy a cow for breeding.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase wadding and fabric to make handycrafts.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong L., 60, is widowed and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnam Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. She has a business of selling various kinds of groceries, which provides an income of about USD 7.13 per day.  L. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to expand her current business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Tang

texts.en: Tang S., 39, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnam Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantation. She and her husband have a business of selling various kinds of groceries for an income of about USD 13.50 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to expand her current business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. (S.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Nabat's Group

texts.en:
Considering all the opportunities that life gives us, one just has to outline a plan of achieving success. Sometimes a staggering success awaits us just some steps ahead and we just have to move a stone which prevents us from seeing the path. Nabat S. is the leader of this group. She is fifty years old. Nabat’s husband works as a security guard. As for Nabat, she offers sewing and tailoring services for local people. Besides this, she has mothered six children: five daughters and a son. Her elder daughters are married and live with their own families. The little daughter is a college student. As for her son, he has gone to Russia in search of work.

Whether it is being a security guard or a seamstress, these occupations are not among well paid activities. However, years of tireless labor have allowed Nabat to buy a house and a car. Nabat’s sister, who actually taught Nabat sewing, could not imagine that this favor of hers would have provided for Nabat her entire life. Nabat’s monthly income is just $115. Nabat has applied for this loan and hopes to buy fabric for making bed linens and towels as she has secured some large orders. 

Nabat’s partners are: 

Parizat C., 45, is a widow. She is engaged in trading in cattle. Parizat has four children. Three of her children work in Russia. Her little son is a school student. Parizat hopes to obtain this loan and buy sheep.

Gulzat K., 37, is a cattle breeder’s wife. They have two children. Both Gulzat and her husband are engaged in breeding cattle. And Gulzat also sells milk. Their monthly income is around $180. Gulzat is in need of a loan. She hopes to buy construction materials for construction. 

Kandalat S., 43, has four children. Her husband has gone to work in Russia. Kandalat keeps sheep and her monthly income is just a little over ten dollars. Kandalat hopes to obtain this loan and build a new fence, which would allow her to keep more sheep.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy fabric for making bed linens and towels.

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben C., 27, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the famous Angkor Wat Temple. She has a tailoring business, which provides an income of about USD 4.00 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver in the province, earning an income of USD 4.00 per day.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more fabrics to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics.

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren is 44 years old and lives with her husband and six children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Byambasuren operates a soldering and manufacturing iron products business with her husband in her town. She has been operating her business since 1999, and has steadily expanded her business and over the years she has gained much experience. Byambasuren and her husband have a loyal customer base, and they manufactured the iron fence along the driveway of the Arvaiheer soum.

Currently, they have been busy with many orders from customers, and they are planning to expand their business and workplace in the future. Byambasuren is a very hardworking person and she is very enthusiastic about the future. She says, “Education is the most important thing for everyone, and I would like to be financially available for my children's studying in the future. In addition, I would like to have my own plot of land with a yard in the future.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug to purchase more iron while the wholesale prices remain low.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Arusha Group

texts.en:
Plilly O., age 50, is married and has six grown children. She has been selling water and bites to eat at a place called Ubungo Maziwa for 10 years now, and is able to earn a monthly profit of around $60.

This will be Pilly's second loan, called a motisha loan, from Tujijenge Tanzania. (A motisha loan is a loan product offered by Tujijenge that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.) She used the first loan to increase her business and has paid it back successfully. Pilly hopes to obtain a loan to further increase her business.
	
Pilly will share this loan with her small loan group Arusha which totals 10 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, Pilly is second from the left.

loans.use: To buy more water and make more bites

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Sopheap H., 24, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the famous Angkor Wat Temple. She has a business of selling various kinds of groceries at home for an income of about USD 5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker in the province, earning an income of USD 5 per day.

Sopheap is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. In the future, and she would like to use any additional profits to pay for the child’s schooling. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: Née en 1977 à Abomey dans le département du Zou, D. Alice est mariée à GIBRIL Aboubacar un conducteur. Alice a trois enfants, tous scolarisés, qui vivent ensemble avec son mari et elle. Il y a six ans environs que Alice s'est installée au quartier Hêvié dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec sa famille. Le couple se partage ensemble les charges familiales. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Alice vend du riz, depuis huit ans. A côté de cette activité, Alice vend également des chaussures, par le système de distribution. C'est à Lomé au Togo, pays limitrophe du Bénin, mais aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Alice achète ses produits. Alice a obtenu une fois déjà de prêt à ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements. Alice sollicite un deuxième prêt, afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de se faire plus de profits après la vente de ses produits.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in the Zou department, Alice D. is married to Aboubacar GIBRIL, who is a driver. Alice has three children,, all attending school, who live together with her and her husband. The family settled some six years ago in the Hêvié borough of the Abomey Calavi commune. The couple jointly shares family expenses. To meet her needs and those of her children, Alice has sold rice for the past eight years. As a side business, she also sells shoes through the distribution system. She gets her products from Lomé in Togo, a country adjacent to Benin, but also from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Alice has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan to increase her supply of products and to bring in more profit once they are sold.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes and three bags of rice

loans.name: Saltanat's Group

texts.en:
A person, who has just started his business, has to know that what he/she is undertaking requires at least as much attention as a person who is trying to build a house with playing cards. Any move, breath, or an awkward gesture can tumble the house. However, provided that needed care, patience and labor is given, the output is a lot more valuable than just a house made of cards. Saltanat T., 29, is the leader of this group. She is unemployed as she has to stay at home with the children. Her husband is a new entrepreneur. He buys sheep in a mountain region, brings them to town, and sells them at the cattle market. He used to do another job, but because of health problems had to get a leave without pay. On one hand he is happy as he has started his business earlier than he thought. If he were to have got this leave later, the opportunities would not be as abundant as this time. Saltanat has applied for this loan to help her husband buy five sheep, bring them to town, and resell them.   

Saltanat’s partners are:

Ainakan A., 49, is a wife of a private builder. Ainakan trades in fish and her monthly income is $240. She hopes to obtain this loan and buy tools for her husband and purchase fish for sale. 

Kubanychbek S., 33, has two children. His wife trades in cell phone cards. Kubanychbek provides for his family by working as an operator at a gas station. He also works as a taxi driver and at weekends he trades in sheep at the cattle market. Kubanychbek needs a loan to buy sheep.

Begayim A., 29, is a mother of two children. Her spouse is a general worker. Begayim is a cook in a kindergarten. She has applied for this loan to buy a car so that her husband could work as a taxi driver.

Kylychbek C., 31, has a son. His wife works as a school teacher. He earns his family’s living by working as a builder. He needs a loan to buy tools for his work.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy five sheep in order to resell them later.

loans.name: Harn

texts.en:
Harn P., 39, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the famous Angkor Wat Temple. She is in the agriculture sector of raising pigs and chickens for an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a local police officer, earning an income of USD 7.50 per day.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase pig food and pigs to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy pig food and pigs.

loans.name: Ange

texts.en:
Ange is 34 years old and is married with three children who are 2, 9 and 12 years old.

Ange struggles by owning a barber shop where she earns money for her daily living. This is her fifth year in this business, even though her earned profits are still too low to expand her business as she wishes.

Ange is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her barbershop by purchasing some additional equipment, mainly clippers, etc.. This, in turn, will help her to increase the number of her customers as well as her profits.

If successful, Ange will continue to provide all the best needs of her children as well as building a secure future for them.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment for her barber shop

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:
Narantuya is 33 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her oldest daughter, Maralmaa, is a secondary school student and her husband works at a stone factory.

Narantuya operates a hat manufacturing business in her town. She produces a variety of hats including fur hats in the winter, woolen hats during the spring and autumn months, and Mongolian traditional hats during the summer. She has been operating her business since 2007, and has steadily expanded her business over the last two years. Narantuya learned to make hats from her sister and previously worked as a salesperson in a local market for six years between 2000-2006. She has good communication skills and is focused on improving her business in the future. She says, “I would like to expand my business.” Narantuya is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan to increase her working capital and purchase more materials for her hat manufacturing business.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth S., 42, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the famous Angkor Wat Temple. She is employed as a chef for an income of about USD 4 per day. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver, earning an income of USD 4 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. With the remainder, she wants to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to pay for the children’s schooling. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. (S.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en:
Bumi is 43 years old, married, and has three children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is a welder and he also supports their home.
Bumi sells medicines to make a living. She loves her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow the business to become bigger and stronger, and she hopes to make more profits. Bumi is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Ya Pom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ya P. is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members. Each group member will use their loan for different purposes. This village bank loan has twenty-two members who live in Chhmar Puon village in Kandal province.

Mrs. Ya P. is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice for supporting her family, and her husband is a construction worker. In the rice field, they have a problem because their field is infertile. Thus, in order to have a productive tobacco crop, Mrs. Ya P. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and rest of the loan she would like to use to hire farmer laborers to plow her field. She is a mother of a child who is too young to go to school or work. All of the members are shown in the picture, but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Ploak

texts.en: Ploak S., 34, is single and resides with her parents in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the famous Angkor Wat Temple. She has a business of selling various kinds of groceries for an income of about USD 4 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her current business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Ramzan's Group

texts.en:
R. is a wife of M. A. and they both live in a city named Vehari in Pakistan. They have a three room house in which they have lived with their family for the past 20 years. R. has given birth to five children: three sons and two daughter. All of them are enrolled in a school and are getting an education. R. and her husband are very hard working people. They run their own grocery shop in the community. They have divided their duties, so R. does her duty in the morning and M. A. does his duty in the grocery shop in the evening. 

They both work hard to increase their income and to give a better future to their kids. R. is requesting a loan to buy items (lentils, cooking oil and beverages) to diversify their grocery shop into a grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase goods for grocery shop.

loans.name: Tayo

texts.en:
Tayo is 41 years old, married, and has five children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband has a bakery and he also supports their home.
Tayo sells medicines to make a living. She loves her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger, and she also hopes to make more profits. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more veterinary medicine

loans.name: Akpelou

texts.fr: Née en 1949 à Adja au Mono, M. Akpelou est mariée à VITOU Emile et est mère de quatre enfants. Akpelou a un autre enfant à sa charge, en plus de ses enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a neuf ans que Akpelou s’est installée à Hêvié , dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. Akpelou participe aux différentes charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui génère son activité. Akpelou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Akpelou vend des condiments de sauce à son domicile. Akpelou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi au marché de Cococodji, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. Akpelou avait bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, et l’a bien remboursé. En vue d’élever le niveau de son activité et de pouvoir mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Akpelou sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1949 in Adja in the Mono region, Akpelou M. is married to Emile VITOU and is the mother of three children. She takes care of another child, in addition to her own. All the children have attended (or are still attending) school. Nine years ago Akpelou settled in Hêvié, in the Abomey Calavi commune. She shares in the management of family expenses thanks to the income generated by her activity. She has never attended school, and for the past ten years has been selling sauce condiments from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and also from the Cococodji market, in the Abomey Calavi commune. Akpelou has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She now is requesting a second loan, to raise the level of her activity and give a better response to customer demands.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baskets of fresh tomatoes and bags of onions

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina C. is a young and hardworking mother of three children whose ages range from 6 to 9 years old. She has been a productive partner to her husband, who is a driver, by having her own businesses. She fattens hogs/pigs and has a “sari-sari” (variety) store. 

These businesses were put up and maintained through the loans she has accessed through ASHI, a Kiva partner. The proceeds of these businesses are a great source for providing her family, including her 68-year-old father and 25-year-old brother, with their basic needs. Though it is small, it is helping her and her family a lot. 

Despite poverty, Gina became hopeful that one day, she will be reaching her dreams by growing her business and having stable profits. With that, she is requesting another loan from ASHI to start another business, which is cattle fattening. Together with the hogs, the cattle will be sold either alive or slaughtered at the public market or to the people in their village.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for fattening

loans.name: Geneviève

texts.fr: Née en  1976 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, T. Geneviève est mariée à REKPE Placide et est mère de deux enfants. Le couple a deux autres enfants à leurs charges. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit à Hêvié, dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi, depuis six ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Geneviève a appris la coiffure, une activité qu’elle mène passionnément depuis une douzaine d’année, et qui lui permet de faire face aux besoins de sa famille. Parallèlement, Geneviève vend dans son atelier de coiffure, des mèches et divers produits de beauté. Geneviève a bénéficié une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements. Face aux exigences de sa clientèle, Geneviève sollicite un deuxième prêt, afin de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter son stock de produits.
texts.en:
Born in 1976 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Geneviève T. is married to Placide REKPE and is the mother of two children. The couple also takes care of two other children. Only some of them have had schooling. The family has been living for the past six years in Hêvié, in the Abomey Calavi commune. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Genevieve has learned hairdressing, an activity she has practiced with passion for over 12 years, and which allows her to meet the needs of her family. As a side business in her beauty salon, Genevieve sells hair extensions and various beauty products. Genevieve has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, and has repaid it in full. Given her customers' demands, she is now requesting a second loan, to strengthen her activity and increase her stock of supplies.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy hair extensions and beauty products

loans.name: Khursheeda's Group

texts.en:
Khursheeda is from the city of Vehari in Pakistan. She owns and operates a business selling women's clothes in the community, and she is passionate about her work. She purchases the clothes from different cities (Lahore and Faisalabad) because of their cheap prices and good quality.
Her husband, M. S. S., operates a fruit-selling business in the food market. He sells his fruits from a cart and also supplies fruits to fruit shops to generate profit. They both work hard to manage their financial expenses and improve their standard of living.
Currently, Khursheeda is requesting a loan to purchase seasonal clothes in bulk so that she is able to complete her customers' orders and earn a good profit.

loans.use: To purchase women's clothes for resale

loans.name: Serikbol

texts.en:
Serikbol is 37 years old and resides with his wife and three children in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a “ger” in Bayan-Ulgii Province, Mongolia. Serikbol and his wife are both disabled and receive assistance from the government. They have three children, the oldest of whom attends a local secondary school. Serikbol, who owns a few cows, currently operates a milk-trading business, selling an average of four liters of milk per day locally at a price of 2000 tugrugs (~ 1 USD ) per litre.

Having found some success since he went into business in 2000, in 2003 Serikbol used his earnings to purchase a motorcycle which he utilizes to operate a taxi service that supplements his income by up to 5000 tugrugs (~ 4 USD) per day. A very hardworking person who is focused on the future, he says, “My dream is to one day have my own cow farm.” He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan to purchase fodder for his cows.

loans.use: To purchase fodder for his cows

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah sells foodstuffs like beans and tubers of yam to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profits. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. 

She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 43 years old and married with two children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband also works to support their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly N., 41, earns $2 per day as a porter. Her husband, Mr. Chou Hor, is also working as a fish porter with her in the same location, where the fish are sold in bulk. They have seven children, two of whom are now married while the remaining five are single. One of their daughters is on the massage staff of a club. 

Ly N. has been building a new house for a long time, but the construction is never completed due to the need for more materials. Because Ly N. lacks money, she is looking for a loan in order to finish building a new house.

loans.use: To finish building a new house

loans.name: Merlie's Group

texts.en:
Merlie L. is from the village of San Rafael, Roxas, Isabela. She is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Merlie L.'s Group.
Merlie is 59 years old, married, and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlie owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Merlie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Merlie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Merlie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Tang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Tang P. is 45 years old and a village bank president for a 13-member group loan. The group is located in Mitakpheap village in Kandal province. Each member will use their loans to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different businesses.
Mrs. Tang P. and her husband, Mr. Roeung Mom, earn a small income through their business selling Chinese noodles in the local village. Mrs. Tang P. is requesting a loan to add to her savings to build her house. Mrs. Tang P. is a mother of five children – one is a police officer, two are at home and support their parents' business, and the other two are students in the local school and also support their parents, too.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a house

loans.name: Reun

texts.en: Mrs. S. is married with four children. She lives in a commune located in Siem Reap Province. She fishes with her husband in a local lake and river, which provides them with enough fish for their family. S. always wakes up early in the morning to go fishing and is back home in the late evening. She then sells the fish that she has caught in the lake from her house. Since fishing is the family's main source of income, S. is requesting a loan of $300 USD to purchase more fishing tools, such as nets and traps, to expand her fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing tools, such as nets and traps

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara is 38 years old and married with four children who attend school which gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also works to support their home. Omolara sells sarongs and loves the business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger and is requesting a loan of N40,000 to buy more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase sarongs to sell

loans.name: Agathe

texts.en:
Agathe is 40 years old and is married with six children who are between 3 and 14 years old. She is a poor woman who works hard in order to provide the daily food for her family.

Agathe is well-known in the business of selling soft drinks. Her business is still simple to the extent that she hardly saves for any circumstance. She has been in this business for about two years and the hours of her business are from 6 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

Agathe needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can add more goods to sell in her shop. Those goods will include foodstuffs like food supplies, sugar, rice, different types of flour, Irish potatoes, and some more drinks like water, juice etc.

With this additional business, Agathe hopes that her profits will increase more than in her previous operation. With those profits, she will try to keep a better sustainability for her business as well as help her children by paying school fees and providing more food for them.

loans.use: To add more goods to sell in her shop

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.en:
Rafoat is a responsible and loving mother who is always thinking of the well-being and security of her children. She is dedicated to raising cattle and sheep. Her husband leaves very early in the morning and travels great distances to provide veterinary services to peasants in need of care for their animals. Rafoat's hope is to purchase more animals to expand her business. To reach this goal, she is requesting a loan of 6,000 TJS.    

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC.
