Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Kpatagnon

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Lomé au Togo, H. Kpatagnon est mariée à GOMEZ Léopold, un chauffeur. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a neuf ans que la famille s'est installée au quartier Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Grâce qu revenu que lui procure son activité, Kpatagnon assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Kpatagnon n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a six ans que Kpatagnon s'est mise à vendre des condiments de sauces, des céréales et divers autres produits (pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomates et de sardine, huile de palme, savons, etc.) à son domicile. Kpatagnon s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé. C'est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Kpatagnon sollicite un troisième prêt, afin d'élargir davantage son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Lomé, Togo, Ms. H. Kpatagnon is married to Mr.  GOMEZ Léopold, a chauffeur.  The couple have two children, who are all in school. Nine years ago, the family settled in the Fiégnon district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Thanks to the income earned by her business, she ensures, along with her husband, that the various family expenses are covered.  Kpatagnon did not attend school.  Six years ago, she started selling sauce condiments, grains, and various other goods (pasta, canned tomatoes and sardines, palm oil, soaps, etc.) out of her home.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and also from Lomé.  She is a good ALIDé client who repays her loans.  She is requesting a third loan in order to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods (canned tomatoes and sardines, palm oil, soaps, pasta)

loans.name: Dayo

texts.en: Dayo is 41 years old and married with four children who attend school, which gives him joy as a father. His wife is a nurse and she also works to support their home. Dayo has a stationery business which he loves because of the opportunity to interact with customers. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger and is requesting a loan of N40,000 to buy more stationery supplies to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy stationery supplies to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sokea Nan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 23 people who live in Chhmar Puon village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sokea N. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. They will all use their loans for different purposes.
Mrs. Sokea N. is a door-to-door tobacco seller, and her husband is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow tobacco to sell to support his family. In the tobacco field, they have a problem because their field has infertile soil. Therefore, in order to improve tobacco production, Mrs. Sokea N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she would like to hire farm laborers to do some of the farming. She is a mother of five children – one is a construction worker, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are enrolled in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Marguba

texts.en:
T. Marguba is a 32-year-old married woman with three children. Her diligent search for a source of additional income has been a permanent and difficult task. After trying her luck at a variety of occupations, Marguba decided to work in the area of animal raising and selling. She started this business seven years ago with the support of her husband. Now that she has experimented and acquired the necessary knowledge regarding this activity, she would like to expand her business by purchasing more sheep. In this way, she hopes to increase her earnings and continue to improve her family’s quality of life.
Marguba is requesting a loan of $1,500 USD. She appeals to your good hearts in her request to make her dream become a reality.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase sheep for breeding and selling

loans.name: Yoeuk

texts.en: The lady in the photo is Yoeuk K.. She is 38 years old and married Chan Hun, 43, many years ago. The couple has four school-aged children. They have a small fishing business in and around Tunle Sap River. By fishing, the couple is able to generate a small income of $5 USD each day, which they use to feed their family. Yoeuk K. is requesting a loan to purchase more fishing accessories for their fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing accessories

loans.name: C4570 Dukundane Group

texts.en:
Florien is 35 years old and is married with four children who are between 3 and 10 years old. He is a hardworking businessman selling bales of clothes and this is his third successful year in this business.

With the purpose of being financially stable, Florien is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to move from the sale of two bales to six bales or more.

With this business expansion, if his sales increase, Florien expects to earn more profits. Those profits will allow him to reinvest in his business as well as build a secure future for his children by paying school fees and providing food for them.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes to sell

loans.name: Basiratu

texts.en:
Basiratu is 35 years old, married, and has three children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband also works to support their home.
Basiratu sells engine oil to make a living. She loves her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger, and she also hopes to make more profits. She is requesting a loan of 60,000 NGN to purchase more engine oil to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva S. is currently in the business of selling maize and millet at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock rice and pulses (groundnuts, peas or cowpeas) to sell.  Eva is 30 years old and married to a peasant. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock rice and pulses (groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) to sell

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
Abibatu K. is a very social and happy woman. She is 36 years old, divorced and has three children, all girls. The eldest is in secondary school and the last two are in primary school. She has been a LAPO, SL client for quite some time now. 

She has a shop in Wilberfore, where she sells provisions. She has taken three previous loans with LAPO, SL, a Kiva partner. Abibatu used her previous loans' profit to build the shop where she sell her goods. 

With the help of LAPO, SL and Kiva lenders, Abibatu wants to use her new loan to purchase more goods and use her profit to see to the needs of her children.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs, cosmetics, drinks and rum

loans.name: Many's Group

texts.en:
In this group loan, there are 13 members located in Mitakpheap village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Many C. is 52 years old and a village bank president who has been selected by the entire group. Each member of the group will use the loan to support different purposes. 

Mrs. Many C. is a village chief and can receive a small salary to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sary Keo, is a farming laborer in the local village. Mrs. Many C. decided to ask for a loan to fix up her house. Mrs. Many C. is the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a small position in an organization.

loans.use: To fix up her house

loans.name: Amonjon

texts.en:
F. Amonjon is 23 years old. He is not married and lives with his parents. Amonjon has been selling curtains for 5 years together with his mother and has gained a rich experience in this kind of business.

Initially Amonjon started with selling clothing with the capital of 100 USD. Gradually he expanded his business and decided to sell curtains as there are few competitors in this kind of business. He has a good taste in choosing curtains when purchasing them which allows him to have a good clientele.

Amonjon wants to continue growing his business to improve his quality of life. For this reason he is requesting a loan of 3000 USD which he will use to buy merchandise and offer products more rapidly as well as fill his pending orders.

Amonjon and his family thank you very much for helping them succeed.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new modern curtains to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase items in bulk for her store

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
To make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state, Rhoda makes lovely hair styles for her customers. She also sells hair materials like cream and hair extensions to boost her business. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more hair materials to sell. 

Rhoda is 36 years old, married with 2 children. Her children are doing well at school and this makes her happy. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: Beauty salon supplies

loans.name: Ko

texts.en:
Every morning, Mrs. Ko C. goes out from her home to buy different kinds of vegetable from farmers. She hurries to bring the vegetables to sell in the local market, from which she earns a living. 

Her husband also earns money by planting rice. Additionally, he has a cultivating machine that he uses to provide a plowing service for a fee. Ko C. has five kids; one is married and the others are single. Two of her sons are construction laborers in Phnom Penh. Ko C. is taking out her loan to buy a used vehicle for her family’s travelling needs. Any remaining cash from the loan, Ko C. will use to repair her existing house which is frequently in need of repairs.

loans.use: To buy a used vehicle

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en:
Isidra B. is from the village of Panalsalan. She is 44 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Isidra owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Isidra has been engaged in her business for over 36 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2005, Isidra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Isidra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Isidra is now requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Isidra from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nelly's Group

texts.en:
Nelly Y. is from the village of Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Nelly is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Nelly is married and has four school-aged children. Nelly owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Nelly has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2007, Nelly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 8000 PHP and which was used purchase additional products to sell.

Nelly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to purchase new items to further expand her product offerings.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni S. is currently in the business of selling rice, maize and millets at the market. She is requesting a loan to buy more bags of maize and rice to sell. Poni is 49 years old and is married to a police man. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize and rice to sell

loans.name: Thavy's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thavy M. is 41 years old and she is the president of a village bank which has 18-members, located in Sleng Kong village in Kandal province. Each member of of the group will use the requested loan to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support different purposes. Mrs. Thavy M. is a pharmacist who earns a small income by selling the medicines to support her family's living expenses. Her husband, Mr. Ratha Sou, is a construction worker and he receives a small salary to support his family. Mrs. Thavy M. is requesting a loan to buy more medicines to enlarge her business in order to increase her income to improve her family's living conditions. Mrs. Thavy M. is the mother of two children; one is a seamstress in the garment factory, and the youngest is just 6 years old.

loans.use: To buy more medicine.

loans.name: Mahinou

texts.fr: Née en 1960 au Mono, A. Mahinou est mariée à COFFI Paul, un entrepreneur. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés, dont seulement deux sont à leurs charges. La famille vit au quartier Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mahinou n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis 10 ans, Mahinou mène comme activité, la vente de céréales (maïs,haricot, etc.) et de l'huile d'arachide à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Mahinou vend des chaussures sandalettes à son domicile. Ces activités lui procurent des revenus qui aident Mahinou à subvenir à ses besoins et à apporter une aide à son mari pour assurer les charges familiales. Mahinou s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Mahinou a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits qu'elle avait obtenu auprès de ALIDé. A présent, afin d'agrandir son activité et d'accroître sa clientèle, Mahinou sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Mono, Ms. A. Mahinou is married to Mr. COFFI Paul, an entrepreneur.  The couple have six children, two of whom they are supporting.  The family lives in the Fiégnon district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Mahinou did not attend school.  For ten years, she has been running a business selling grains (corn, beans, etc.) and peanut oil out of her home.  And she sells flip-flop sandals on the side.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  This business brings in the income that helps her to support herself and to bring assistance to her husband for making sure that family expenses are covered.  Mahinou has repaid the first two loans she had obtained from ALIDé.  At present, in order to expand her business and to grow her customer base, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying beans and containers of peanut oil

loans.name: Jarlie

texts.en:
Jarlie S. is a simple and industrious woman who spends her life loving and caring for her husband and two children, ages two and seven. She happily handles her career being a wife, mother and businesswoman. She started her own business when she joined ASHI in 2008 and received a loan. 

Her desire to give her children a better kind of life in the future inspired her to have her own business and augment her husband’s sporadic income as a hired laborer. First, she started selling vegetables and in her next loans, she started hog fattening and a “sari-sari” (variety) store.  To market her products, she sells them directly to people in their village and in a public market. 

Now, Jarlie is requesting another loan from ASHI to support her businesses and to grow them further until such time that they become profitable and stable. For her store, she wants to increase its inventory for the convenience of her customers who live around their village.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Ry

texts.en:
Mrs. Ry C. is 56 years old and she is a villager who lives in Boeng Krum Leu village in Kandal province. She is a pig breeder who can earn a small income to support her family.  She needs a loan to buy pig food and to dig a well for selling water. Her husband, Mr. Son Chhim, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field to cultivate rice. 

This couple has six children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is staying at home and supports the parents' businesses while the other three are students in the local school. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: Pig feed and well digging

loans.name: Kadia

texts.en:
Kadia J., currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut phase, is requesting a loan to stock bags of charcoal to sell. Kadia, a 30-year-old mother of two children who both attend school, is married to a clerk. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land and build a permanent house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Lauriana's Group

texts.en:
Lauriana R. is from the village of Rang-Ayan, Roxas, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Lauriana is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lauriana R.' Group.

Lauriana is married and has three school-aged children. Lauriana owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lauriana has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Lauriana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 11,000 PHP and which was used purchase additional products to sell.

Lauriana is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to to expand the business. This loan will be her fourth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand it.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.en:
Sharofat H., 33 years old and married, is the loving mother of two children. She lives in Dushanbe and owns a small vending store in the local market. For about two years Sharofat has been selling the national coat “Chapan” for men and national dresses for women. Her store is well-known in the market for having a nice variety of assorted merchandise at affordable prices, and her profits have increased considerably since she started her business. Sharofat has a unique ability to analyze a merchandise market and find her niche, a skill that helped her start her business and make it successful. Today, in order to increase inventory and sales, she is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni. With your help this will be possible.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Adiatou

texts.fr: Née en 1984, A. Adiatou est mariée à IBRAHIM Abdoulaye, un soudeur, et est mère de deux enfants. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge.  Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Il y a près de huit ans que la famille s’est installée à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Adiatou exerce comme activité la vente de divers produits (savons, piles, sucre, lait, conserves de tomate et de sardine, pâtes alimentaires, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin que Adiatou achète ses produits. Adiatou a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Adiatou souhaite renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Pour ce faire, Adiatou sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1984, Ms. A. Adiatouis is married to Mr. IBRAHIM Abdoulaye, a welder, and is the mother of two children.  The couple have another children in their care.  Of these children, some are in school.  The family settled in Djeffa, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, nearly eight years ago. Together, the couple are sharing the various family expenses.  To meet her needs, Adiatou has a business selling a variety of goods (soaps, batteries, sugar, milk, canned tomatoes and sardines, pasta, etc.) out of her home.  She purchases her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She once obtained a loan from ALIDé.  She wishes to bolster her business and to respond better to the demands of her customers.  To do so, Adiatou is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a variety of goods (soap, milk, sugar, canned tomatoes and sardines, etc.)

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola sells medicines and groceries to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profit. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more medicines to sell. 

Bola is 45 years old and married with five children. Her children are doing well in business and at school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband sells electronics to support their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
Saodat sells nice, quality fabrics for national dresses in a big local market. Her family is actively helping her with her business which she started about 15 years ago. Saodat would like to ask for a loan of 7,000 Somoni to increase her inventory stock which will help supply her until the spring season. She believes this timely investment will help her generate additional income and increase the family budget. We think Saodat’s responsibility and strong character will assist her in the current loan repayment.

loans.name: Mabatini Group

texts.en:
Abdul M., age 32, is married with three children, ages 10, 8 and 5. He has had a clothing shop at a place called Tandika for five years now. He works from 8:30 am to 8:30 pm and he is able to make a monthly profit of about $415.

This will be Abdul’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to start selling DVDs, radios and antennas, and he has paid back the loan successfully. He hopes for a loan to increase his DVD, Radio and antenna business.

Abdul will share this loan with subgroup B, of Mabatini Group, which totals six members. These members sell food, fruit, DVD players, radios and clothing. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Abdul is the only man.

loans.use: To increase  DVD, radio and antenna stock

Dudu A. is currently in the business of operating a pharmacy and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell.  Dudu is 39 years old and is married to a husband that is a nurse. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

Romana is 54 years old and manages a sari-sari (variety) store. She’s been in business for 20 years.  Joining Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in 2003 has helped her improve her business. She takes care of four children in her family. She wishes for them to have a bright future.

She is currently asking a loan of 17,000 PHP to purchase groceries for her store to help her sustain her business.

She and her husband, Mr. Yoeun Teang, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow crops to earn a living for their family. Mrs. Rum P. is requesting a loan to dig a well and with the rest of the loan she wants to buy cement to support her well. Mrs. Rum P. is a mother of a child who is a seamstress in the garment factory. Her husband is on the left in the picture.

texts.en:
Adeola sells VCDs and juice to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profit. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more VCDs and juice to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Thon Phoem Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nineteen people who live in Chrey Young village in Kandal Province comprise this village bank loan group, led by Mrs. Thon P. who, along with her husband, grows vegetable for sale on their plot of land. Through this activity, they support four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other two are studying in local public school. Unfortunately, their field is currently infertile, S. in order to improve vegetable production, Thon is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Barno

texts.en: Problems and money shortages never defeated Barno, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and continue to improve her situation. She is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. She is 43 years old, married, and the loving mother of four children. Barno started her own business because her husband’s salary was not enough for their family expenses. For more than fourteen years she has operated a store where she sells women’s shoes. Her store is well known and people love to visit it because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Barno hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her family, especially for her children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more shoes to sell. With this purpose in mind, Barno requests 8,000 Somoni. She promises to repay the loan on time and thanks everyone supporting her. loans.name: Yory

texts.en:
Mrs. Yory Y. is 62 years old and she is a villager who lives in Roboah Angkanh village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Bich Khoem, are able to earn a living through their farm crops. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

Mrs. Yory Y. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows crops. In this farming, she does not have enough money to support her farm crops. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline to support her purpose.

Mrs. Yory Y. is the mother of four children: one is a seamstress in the garment factory, one is a farmer who supports the parents’ farming, while the other two are students in the local school.

In this faming, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to support their farm crops. Thus, Mrs. Phou L. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to support the farm crops.

Mrs. Phou L. is the mother of six children: one is a seamstress in the garment factory while the others are students in the local school and also support their parents’ farming.

loans.name: Fredeswinda

texts.en: Fredeswinda U. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 70 years old, is widowed, and has six adult children. Fredeswinda owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Fredeswinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Fredeswinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Mojisola

Designing clothes is a business activity that Mojisola loves so much. She designs lovely Nigerian and Western patterns for her customers. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers.

She is 46 years old and married with three children. Her children are excelling in school and this makes her happy as a mother. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Luzminda's Group

texts.en:
Luzminda D., from the village of District 1, is the 44-year-old group leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Luzminda D.'s Group.

Luzminda, who is married and has three school-aged children, sells seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Luzminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan, her ninth, of 10000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. Luzminda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Julienne N.

texts.fr: F. Julienne N. est née le 14 avril 1986 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Julienne N. vit depuis environs sept ans à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Julienne N. est mariée à NATOUNTONDE Edmond, un chauffeur, avec qui elle a trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Le couple a également à charge un quatrième enfant. Julienne N. vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assume ensemble les divers besoins des enfants. En effet, pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, Julienne N. vend des produits cosmétiques à son domicile. Julienne N. effectue l’achat de ses produits à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin et à Cotonou également. Julienne N. fait son commerce depuis bientôt cinq ans. ALIDé a déjà accordé un crédit à Julienne N., crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Dans le but de renforcer son stock pour faire face aux divers besoins de sa clientèle, Julienne N. sollicite un deuxième crédit chez ALIDé.
texts.en:
Julienne N. F. was born 14 April 1986 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. For seven years Julienne N. has lived in Djeffa, in the Sèmè-Podji commune. She is married to Edmond NATOUNTONDE, a driver, with whom she has three children, some attending school. The couple also cares for a fourth child. Julienne N. lives together with her children and her husband, with whom she shares responsibility for meeting the children’s needs. In fact Julienne N. sells beauty products from her home to help manage family expenses. She buys her products in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, and also in Cotonou. She has now been running her business for almost five years. She has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. To bolster her stock to meet her customers’ various needs, Julienne N. is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Toychieva Mohidilhon`s Group

texts.ru:
Тойчиева Мохидилхон является лидером этой группы. В этой группе собрались 4 участника, которые хотят, чтобы их жизнь стала лучше, и они надеятся друг на друга.  Лидер группы занимается сельским хозяйством, а именно выращиванием кукурузы, риса. Кредит запрашивается для закупа семян хлопчатника и удобрения.  У Мохидилхон 3 детей. Старшие двое учатся в школе. Супруг работает сварщиком на дому, в основном изготавливает металлические ворота.

Мехринисо, 29, замужем. У нее двое детей дошкольного возраста. Супруг работает строителем в Бишкеке. Вместе с свекровкой она занимается сельским хозяйством. В этом году планируют посеять хлопок, кредит нужен для закуп семян. 

Ахмаджану 61 год. Он пенсионер, и все свое свободное время занимается домашним хозяйством. А его супруга занимается предоставлением услуг пошива на заказ женских одежд и национальных изделий в месяц зарабатывает около 75 долларов.На кредит планирует закупить семена хлопчатника, и минеральные удобрения.

Тавакилхон, 58, замужем. Супруг уехал на заработки в РФ, там работает электриком. Клиент в данное время пенсионер, до пенсия работала акушеркой в районной больнице. В данное время она занимается животноводством окормом и разведением коров. На кредит  клиентка планирует закупить на 15К две телки, и на остальную сумму семена хлопчатника и минеральное удобрение  и расходовать на ГСМ.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Mohidilhon T. is the leader of this group. The group consists of 4 participants, who wish that their lives become better and reply on each other. The group leader is involved in agriculture, specifically, in growing corn and rice. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of cotton seeds and fertilizers. Mohidilhon has 3 children. The oldest two go to school. Her husband works as a welder at home and primarily makes metal gates. Mehriniso is 29 years old, married. She has two children of pre-school age. Her husband is a construction worker in Bishkek. Mehriniso and her mother-in-law are involved in agriculture. This year, they plan to plant cotton and need the loan to buy seeds. Ahmadjan is 61 years old. He is retired and spends all of his free time taking care of the household business. And his wife is involved in providing sewing services and makes-to-order women’s clothing and national goods. She earns about 75 dollars per month. Ahmadjon plans to use the loan for the purchase of cotton seeds and mineral fertilizers. Tavakilhon is 58 years old, married. Her husband left to work in the Russian Federation, where he works as an electrician. The client is currently retires and worked as a midwife at the district hospital. She is currently involved in animal husbandry – fattening and breeding cattle. The client plans to use 15k of the loan to buy two cows and use the rest of the sum to buy cotton seeds, mineral fertilizers and fuel.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cotton seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sylviane

texts.fr: D. Sylviane est née le 21 avril 1968 et vit depuis maintenant sept ans à Aïdjedo, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés, Sylviane est mariée à ZOFOUN Christophe, un soudeur. Sylviane vit seule avec ses enfants mais est aidée par son mari pour assurer les divers besoins des enfants. En effet, pour contribuer à l’éducation scolaire de ses enfants, Sylviane mène comme activité,  la vente de divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, piles, papiers hygiéniques, conserves, huile, etc.) à son domicile. Sylviane s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Sylviane a arrêté les classes au cours primaire mais exerce son activité depuis environs huit ans. Sylviane a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Dans l’espoir d’élever le niveau de son activité, Sylviane sollicite un deuxième prêt chez ALIDé.
texts.en:
Sylviane D. was born 21 April 1968 and has been living for the past seven years in the Aïdjedo borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school, Sylviane is married to Christophe ZOFOUN, a welder. She lives alone with her children but is assisted by her husband in meeting the children’s various needs. In fact, to contribute to her children’s education, Sylviane has been retailing various products from her home (pasta, batteries, toilet paper, canned goods, vegetable oil, etc.). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She stopped going to school at primary level, and has been running her business for almost eight years. Sylviane has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan, with the hope of raising her level of activity.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy containers of vegetable oil, canned goods and pasta

loans.name: Olateju

texts.en: Olateju sells clothes, shoes and bags to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profits. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN120,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She is 37 years old, married, and has 3 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: Shamim A. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans. Shamim is 40 years old and is widowed. She has one child and her child does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of rice and beans

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat sells clothes to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profits. She loves this business because of the opportunity it gives her to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is 31 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She hopes to pull her family and business out of poverty. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en: Kemi sells food and grocery items to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profits. She loves this business because of the opportunity it gives her to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN100,000 to purchase more food and grocery items to sell. She is 40 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband also works to supports their home. She hopes to pull her family and business from poverty. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food and groceries to sell.

loans.name: Goussi

texts.fr: Née en 1944, A. Goussi est mariée à AHOUSSOU Dansi, un agent de sécurité. Goussi est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés, dont seulement trois sont à sa charge. La famille vit à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Goussi vient en aide à son mari et contribue aux différentes charges de la famille. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Goussi vend depuis près de 15 ans, du "sodabi" (boisson alcoolisée locale) au quartier Gbèdjromédé à Cotonou. Goussi achète son produit à Agolin dans le département du Zou. Goussi a obtenu une fois déjà un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. En vue de renforcer son activité et de rehausser le stock de son produit, pour vendre davantage son produit, Goussi sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1944, Goussi A. est mariée à Dansi AHOUSSOU, a security agent. Goussi is the mother of four children, all having attended (or still attending) school, and of whom only three are still under her care. The family lives in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Goussi helps her husband by contributing towards the various family expenses. Never having attended school, Goussi has been selling “sodabi” (a local alcoholic beverage) for the past 15 years, in the Gbèdjromédé borough of Cotonou. She buys her product in Agolin in the Department of Zou. She has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan to strengthen her business, increase her stock supply and sell more of her product.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy “sodabi” (a local alcoholic beverage)

loans.name: Alieva Nakylai`s Group

texts.ru:
Накылай,  53, вдова. У нее 7 детей. Сыновья на заработках в Бишкеке, , дочь шьет шторы на заказ, младшая дочь заканчивает 11 класс, а младший сын учится в 8 классе. Клиент занята животноводством: откор и разведение КРС и реализация молочных изделий. Бизнес был начать в 2002 году у заемщицы был маленький теленок купленный на свои сбережения, через два года тот теленок давал 7-8 литров молока в день. На кредит планирует купить дойную корову.

Еркиной, 26, она замужем и мать 2 дочерей, оба ходят в детский сад. Клиент занимается выращиванием подсолнуха. В земледелии ей помогает мать. 'На кредит клиентка планирует закупить минеральные удобрения (100кг) и строй материалы для ремонта дома.

Кандалатхан 46 лет. ее  супруг находится на заработках в РФ. У нее трое дочерей. 'СТаршая дочь учится в ВУЗе , средняя дочь заканчивает в этом году 11 класс , младшая дочь учится в 8-м классе. Сама же занята оптовой и розничной реализацией фруктов и овощей. Кредит запрашивается для закупа овощей (оптом ) для розничной реализации (картофель , лук, морковь).

Гузалой живет вместе с родителями супруга, т.к. супруг также в данное время работает в России. У нее есть одна дочь. За ней присматривает ее свекровка. Гузалой занята в сфере оптовой и розничной реализации фруктов в Араване. Кредит будет использован для закупа фруктов.

Хосилжону 41 год. Он женат, супруга работает поваром в столовой. Заемщик выращивает картофель и хлопчатник . Заемщик уже посадил на 0.80га картофель , на остальную часть земли 0.70га планирует посадить хлопчатник. 'На кредит он закупит 100кг мин. удобрения, семена хлопчатника 50кг, распохать землю и купить ГСМ для трактора.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Nakylai is 53 years old, a widow. She has 7 children. The sons work in Bishkek, a daughter sews widow drapes to-order, the youngest daughter is finishing 11th grade in school, and the youngest son is in 8th grade. The client is involved in animal husbandry: fattening and breeding cattle and selling dairy products. Nakylai started the business in 2002 with a small calf that she purchased with her own savings. Two years later, this calf produced 7-8 liters of milk per day. Nakylai plans to use this loan to buy a dairy cow. Erkinoy is 26. She is married and a mother of 2 daughters, both of whom go to kindergarten. The client is involved in growing sunflowers. Her mother helps her with this business. Erkinoy plans to use the loan to buy mineral fertilizers (100 kg) and building materials for house repairs. Kandalathan is 46 years old. Her husband is in the Russian Federation for work. She has three daughters. The oldest one is attending a university, middle daughter is finishing 11th grade this year, and the youngest is in 8th grade. Kandalathan is involved in wholesale and retail sales of fruits and vegetables. She is requesting the loan for the wholesale purchase of vegetables in order to sell retail (potatoes, onions, carrots). Guzaloy lives with her husband’s parents because her husband also currently works in Russia. She has one daughter. Guzaloy’s mother-in-law looks after her. Guzaloy is involved in wholesale and retail sales of fruits in Aravan. She will use the loan to buy fruits. Hosiljon is 41 years old. He is married. His wife works as cook at a cafeteria. Hosiljon grows potatoes and cotton. He already planted 0.8 ha of potatoes and plans to use the rest of the land (0.70 ha) to plant cotton. He wants to use the loan to buy 100 kg of mineral fertilizers, 50 kg of cotton seeds, to plow the land and buy fuel for a tractor.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow

loans.name: Olaide

texts.en:
Olaide sells cooked foods to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profit. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and to sell. 

Olaide is 27 years old and married with two children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband also works to support their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo sells medicines to make a living. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to own a big pharmacy stall in the future. 

Taiwo is 28 years old and married without children. Her husband works to support their home. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more medicines to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is the wife of P. M. and lives in a small city named Raiwind in Pakistan. She has a three-roomed house and has been living in it for the past twenty-five years. She has given birth to a single daughter who is seven years old and reads in 2nd standard in a local school.

Nasreen owns and operates a business sewing clothes. She sews clothes for her neighborhood ladies and charges them these rates: designer clothes stitching - Pak Rs. 150; simple stitching - Pak Rs. 100. Her customers are satisfied with the rates and never argue with her about it.

Nasreen’s husband runs a grocery shop in the main market where he sells food (biscuits, chips and sweets). His limited items have made his business of interest only to kids. But Nasreen is now requesting a loan to diversify his grocery shop products with lentils, cooking oil, rice, beverages, etc., so that he is able to increase the number of his customers and earn more profit.

loans.use: To buy diversified goods for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: C2905 Abazamurana Group

texts.en:
Irene is 31 years old and is married with three children aged 6, 4 and 2 years. Her husband is a farmer and both they work hardly for their family. Irene is honest and serious in her daily activities and that is the reason why she is selected as group representative. This group is called Abazamurana in local language and contains five members, most of them are women except one who is a man. Their businesses are different: some of them sell shoes and another one owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products.

Irene is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase various styles of shoes for sale as well as additional colors. Through accessing this loan, if her plans are successful, Irene will be able to continue her life as a self-employed woman with a successful enterprise.

loans.use: To purchasing a larger variety of shoes

loans.name: Rita

texts.fr: D. Rita est née en 1968 à Allada dans le département de l’atlantique. Il ya très longtemps que Rita vit à Allomey, à Allada. Mariée à TODJO Dorothée, un agent de la poste, Rita est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Rita vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour subvenir aux divers besoins de ses enfants, Rita vend des liqueurs non loin de son domicile. Rita fait ses provisions à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rita a peu fréquenté l’école mais exerce son activité depuis fort longtemps.  ALIDé a déjà accordé un crédit à Rita, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Rita souhaite accroître son chiffre d’affaire, c’est la raison pour laquelle elle sollicite un deuxième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Rita D. was born in 1968 in Allada in the "département" (administrative district) of Atlantique. She has lived in Allomey in Allada for a very long time. Married to Dorothée TODJO, a post office worker, Rita is mother to two children who are both at school. Rita lives with her husband and children. The couple shares responsibility for supporting the family. In order to provide for her children's various needs, Rita sells liqueurs not far from her home. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Rita attended school very little but has been carrying out her business for a very long time. ALIDé has already granted one loan to Rita, which she repaid correctly. Rita would like to increase her turnover and for this reason she is applying for a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ten boxes of liqueurs

loans.name: C2903 Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Clementine is 19 years old and is married with two children: the firstborn is 2 years old and the youngest is 9 months old. Clementine's husband is a farmer; both work for the welfare of their family.

Clementine is the leader of group which is called Tuzamurane in the local language. This group contains four people, all of them businesswomen.

Clementine has an experience of five years selling various products, mainly foodstuffs. Her shop is open from six in the morning to seven in the evening, every day - even during the weekend. Clementine is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products for her shop.

The target of Clementine and her group is to satisfy their customers’ demands and to attract more customers. With this attraction, Clementine and group will be able to earn more profit which will help them to sort out their family problems.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran is a wife of M. S. and they both live in a small city named Raiwind in Pakistan. She is a very caring lady. She gets up early in the morning and readies her two children, one son and one daughter, for their schools and prepares breakfast for them and for her husband too. 
 
Her husband operates a wood-selling business. He has been in this profession for the past 10 years. He sells the wood in the community and generates income. His income is the main source of income for his family. Currently, Sugran’s husband needs a loan to buy wood in bulk to meet the orders of his customers and to generate good profit.

loans.use: To buy wood in bulk to meet the orders of her husband's customers

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses O. is a hardworking man. He sells planks in Oyo State, Nigeria. He is a happy man who has been in this business for a long time. He is 56 years old and married with six children. His children are doing well in business and school. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more planks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Hanifan's Group

texts.en:
Hanifan is from the small city of Raiwind in Pakistan. She has a very friendly nature and always keeps a smile on her face. While she is not an educated lady, she has good talking skills and good understanding.
Hanifan has owned and operated a grocery shop in the community for over three years. She enjoys handling her grocery shop and keeps herself busy in it. Her husband, M. A., works in a local factory for a meager income. Hanifan's business allows her to meet the financial expenses of the family.
Currently she is requesting a loan to buy more groceries, such as lentils, cooking oil and spices, for the expansion of her grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy goods for grocery shop

loans.name: Kosar Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Kosar Parveen is a wife of M. R. and lives in the small city of Raiwind in Pakistan. She has a three-roomed house in which she has lived with her family for the past 20 years. Her husband has a fruit-selling business. He purchases fruits from the fruit markets and sells them on his fruit cart by travelling to various areas in the community.
Kosar runs a grocery shop in the community to share the financial burden with her husband. She also saves part of her income for rainy days. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s fruit-selling business by buying seasonal fruits in bulk.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits in bulk for resale

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar is a 38-year-old married woman with three children. She lives in the small city of Raiwind in Pakistan. She has a two-roomed brick house where she has been living with her family for the past 15 years.
Kosar is a very enthusiastic lady. She operates a business embroidering dupattas (a garment worn with traditional dresses in Asian countries). She embroiders them and then sells them at the clothes markets. She does this work to support her husband, M. N. Khan, who works in a dairy business. He gets milk from his dairy cow and sells it to milk shops. He earns approximately 15,000 PKR per month. Kosar is applying for a loan to buy another dairy cow to expand her husband’s dairy business.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Saidia

texts.en:
Saidia A. is 40 years old and married to a teacher. She has seven children who all go to school. She is currently in the business of selling maize, sorghum and millet at the market. Saidia is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and rice to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius M. M. is seventy years old. He is married and has been blessed with eight children. His business is located in the entrance of the busy jogoo market in Nairobi. He sells soft drinks to the people who have businesses within jogoo market and also walk-ins who come in to shop from the market. 

He has been in this business for the last forty-seven years and he says that this kind of business also needs to be marketed. He is using his loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more soft drinks to sell to people and expand his business. He does not plan to change this business as it it something he has grown to love doing. He is hardworking, humble, and ambitious.

loans.use: Soft drinks

loans.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan lives in the small city of Raiwind in Pakistan. Her house consists of three big rooms, and she has lived there with her family for the past 30 years. Sharifan is a seamstress by profession and sews clothes for her neighbors in order to earn an income. She uses her income to pay for utilities. She also saves a part of her income for rainy days.
Her husband, A. P., has a wood-selling business. He supplies wood for tandoors (ovens made from mud and used to prepare bread). He also sells wood in the community. People purchase wood for cooking food since gas is not available in their community. Sharifan is applying for a loan to buy more wood in bulk to expand her husband’s wood-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase wood in bulk for resale

loans.name: Artur

texts.en:
Artur M. was born in 1978. He lives with his wife, son and daughter in Ijevan city. During 1999-2001 he worked as a history teacher in Vazashen village, Ijevan area. Since 2001 Artur is engaged in a food and household goods trading business in his own trade place. With the profit from his business Artur bought a utility truck without a carbody, and also solves his family's financial needs. 
Artur asks for 1.000.000 AMD loan to buy a carbody for his utility truck, which will help him with his shop’s merchandise transportation.

loans.use: To buy a carbody for his utility truck.

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is married with a three-year-old son. She is a farmer from Gladkovka, Kherson region. She owns greenhouses and grows early spring vegetables such as cucumbers, peppers, cabbages, etc. Alla launched this venture seven years ago. Since then she has invested over 17,000 UAH in this business. Currently, her net profit amounts to 3,500 UAH.
Alla is requesting a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase agricultural fiber, seeds, fertilizers and chemical pesticides. She believes improved fertilizers and planting conditions will help her double the yields of some major crops, thus bringing her additional income as a result.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural fiber, seeds, fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Oleksyi

texts.en:
Oleksyi is married with a daughter. He is a farmer from Gladkovka, Kherson region. He grows tomatoes, cucumbers and potatoes in his greenhouses for selling retail in the marketplaces of his region. His greenhouses are built on his private land, which is his secure and reliable asset. Oleksyi built his first greenhouse four years ago. He has invested 40,000 UAH into this venture. Every month, he receives about 18,000 UAH of income.
Oleksyi is seeking a 10,000 UAH loan to purchase a drip irrigation unit for his greenhouses. He will also buy agricultural fiber, fertilizers, chemical pesticides and wood. Lending assistance will help him improve conditions in his greenhouses thus facilitating the growth of his vegetables and ensuring their timely ripening. Oleksyi has proved to be a responsible borrower who distributes finances wisely and always repays his loans on time.

loans.use: To purchase a drip irrigation unit, as well as other farming supplies

loans.name: Gerald

texts.en: Gerald G. M. is 27 years old, married and has one child, who is five years old. He owns a general store located at Shauri moyo, a busy part of Nairobi, where he sells items such as sugar, salt, flour, oil and other fast-moving consumer items. He has been in this business for 11 years and also runs a barber shop and restaurant. He has applied for a loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more items to sell to his customers. In the future, he wants to buy land which he can later develop. He is widely known as a hardworking and caring person.

loans.use: to buy sugar, flour, cooking oil and other items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Bendo

texts.en:
Bendo V. is 40 years old and married to a policeman. She has two children who go to school. V. is currently in the business of selling maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock cassava flour to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock cassava flour to sell

loans.name: Ishenbaeva Mukaramkan`s Group

texts.ru:
Мукарамкан 44 года. Она замужем. Ее супруг работает замначальником по кадрам Кадамжайского отделения внутренних дел. У нее трое детей. Старшие двое учатся в ВУЗе, а младший сын школьник. Клиент занимается торговлей фарфоровой посуды на дому. Кредит запрашивается для закупа двух комплектов посуды для реализации. 


Айдан 54 года. Ее супруг пенсионер. Клиент сама занимается разведением и перепродажей МРС. Данным бизнесом клиентка начала заниматься 20 лет назад. У неё были хорошие условия для разведения живности, она решила попробовать, и дело пошло в гору. Сейчас у нее имеются 20 коз и стабильный доход.  Кроме этого, клиентка занимается выращиванием зерновых и овощных культур. Кредит нужен чтобы купить 250 кг кунжары для откорма коз.

Урпия,36, разведена. У нее двое детей. Она работает частным нотариусом, также занимается пошивом нац-х изделий на дому. В детстве её бабушка занималась пошивом таких изделий. Потом она воплотила в жизнь свои навыки, полученные ещё в детстве. На кредит она планирует купить швейную машинку.

Зулайхо также как и Мукарамкан занимается торговлей фарфоровой посуды. По сути именно она и порекомендовала этот бизнес Мукарамкан. Она также хочет купить новую продукцию для реализации.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Mukaramkan is 44 years old. She is married. Her husband works as an assistant personnel director at the Kadamjai department of internal affairs. Mukaramkan has three children. The oldest two attend a university, and the youngest is a school student. The client is involved in retail sales of porcelain dishware at home. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of two sets of dishware for subsequent sale. Aydan is 54 years old. Her husband is retired. The client is involved in breeding and sales of small livestock. Aydan started this business 20 years ago. She had good conditions for breeding livestock, so she decided to give it a try, and the business went uphill. Now she has 20 goats and a stable income. Besides this business, Aydan is also involved in growing grain and vegetable crops. She needs a loan to buy 250 kg of goat feed in order to feed the goats. Urpiya is 36, divorced. She has two children. She works as a notary public and also sews national goods at home. Her grandmother used to sew such goods when Urpiya was a child. Urpiya was able to utilize these skills that she learned ever since her childhood. She wants to use the loan to buy a sewing machine. Zalayho, just like Mukaramkan, is involved in sales of porcelain dishware. Actually, she is the one who recommended this business to Mukaramkan. Zalayho also wants to buy new products for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of two sets of dishware

loans.name: Kaku

texts.en:
Kaku A. is 25 years old and married to a driver. She has four children who all go to school. She is currently in the business of selling various items in her shop, such as soap, sugar, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more boxes of biscuits and soap. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to extend the floor of her shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more boxes of biscuits and soap

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 25 years old and he is still single.  Emmanuel is known as a proven entrepreneur baking breads, cakes, and some other pastries for sale.  This is his third successful year in this business.  He employs 17 people in his business and the hours of the business are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Although Emmanuel has been in this business for about three years, his seed money is still too low to satisfy all his customer's needs.  To end this, Emmanuel is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he hopes that he will satisfy all the demands of his customers and hopefully his profits will increase. He will reinvest the profits in the business and save for his future.

loans.use: To purchase breads, cakes, and some other pastries for sale

loans.name: Marie Gorette

texts.en:
